 REPUBLIC OF CROATIA FARMER SUPPORT SERVICES PROJECT Loan and Project Summary Borrower: Republic of Croatia Executing Agencg: Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry Beneficiary: Private farmers Amount: US$17.0 miilion equivalent Terms: 17 years, including five years of grace, at the level repayment of principals (LRP), at standard IBRD variable interest rate. Objectives: The project would support the transition of the agriculture sector by providing technology-related support services that are relevant to the private farmers. The aim is to improve the income of the private farming community and increase its productivity and hence the competitiveness of the sector. The project would (i) change the delivery of technical services to the private farming community and (ii) restructure and strengthen institutions to meet the needs of a market economy. Description: The proposed project consists of six components: (i) Extension, (ii) Research, (iii) Animal Health, (iv) Pasture and Fodder Development, (v) Seed Industry Development, and (vi) Policy Analysis Support. The project would: (i) modernize agriculture practices and farm management through private and public agriculture extension involving farmers in the services; (ii) improve the applied agriculture research management system ensuring farmers' participation in the formulation of the research agenda; (iii) strengthen the private and public veterinary services and, in particular, the epidemiological services; (iv) assist in the development of the country's grassland and pasture potential; (v) provide the regulatory and institutional framework for the seed industry; and (vi) improve the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry policy analysis and formulation capabilities; and strengthen the agriculture data base available to policy decision-makers.
 - ii - Benefits: Private farmers will be the principal beneficiaries, gaining advantage from improved production technology and animal health services, a strengthened regulatory framework for the seeds industry, and from government policies and services more conducive to the development of a vigorous private agricultural sector. The project would contribute to improving living standards in rural areas in which small-scale agriculture is a major employer and source of income. The project will also generate substantial public benefits: disease control and livestock product sanitary inspection will reduce losses; and improved agricultural production and policy would foster better resource utilization. Risks: The potential resistance at the operational level by the various Government institutions and services involved in the project to give up traditional influence and responsibilities following their reorganization is a risk associated with the project. This would be addressed through a substantial training program for the staff of these institutions with a focus on farm community participation and on the rationale for the changes introduced under the project. Associated to this is the risk of a slow establishment of an Agriculture Research Council and a National Seed Authority. This is being addressed through considerable technical assistance provided both during pre-project start-up using Japanese grant funds, and during early project implementation to work out procedures and to assist these nascent institutions. A second risk lies in the number and size of procurement contracts to be implemented during the first project years; to mitigate a procurement specialist has already been hired to compile the major packages to be procured during the first project year. A third risk during implementation stems from limited farmer capacity to form and support private associations, and the potential limitations of extension and research staff to evolve with the market economy. This risk will be counteracted by project activities which will focus technology development on efficiency increases, improved farm management practices and product diversification; the assurance of unequivocal Government support to farmer associations and farmer guided extension and research services; and a focus of project design on farm community participation.

 REPUBLIC OF CROATIA FARMER SUPPORT SERVICES PROJECT CHAPTER I. BACKGROUND A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Croatia's agriculture economy was stagnant during the 1980's and declined sharply at independence due to war and the associated loss of land and livestock resources. The origin of the stagnation in the 1980's lies in the economic policies of the former Yugoslavia: an inequitable division of resources between the private and the social sectors, inadequate fiscal and monetary policies, over-capacities in agro-industry, and domestic market protection. Agrarian policy was not, however, as rigidly collectivist in Croatia as in countries under central planning. For instance, Yugoslavia's Constitution of 1974 allowed unlimited leasing of land, and by the end of the 1980s the limit on land ownership had been raised to 30 ha; the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia places no limit on the size of private landholding. 1.2 Private farming enjoyed government support in the former Yugoslavia only to the extent that it benefited the social and cooperative agro-industrial subsector. Agricultural technology development was focused on large scale farming and aimed at production maximization, paying insufficient attention to economic sustainability. While some private farmers adapted this technology to meet their needs, most learned and applied technology which is now widely recognized as being inappropriate in a market economy. Although a body of technology exists and more can be gleaned from the practices of successful private farmers, there remains the need to restructure and reorient the agriculture knowledge system. This includes rebuilding its structure and management, giving it a market focus, making it responsive and accountable to the private farming community and ensuring its future financial sustainability. Other support services, such as veterinary services, and the regulatory framework for the seed industry require considerable institutional reforms in order to overcome the legacy of the past and to increase participation of the private farming community. Policy formulation capabilities need to be developed in order to ensure more rational agriculture policies. 1.3 The Croatian Government is committed to the development of the private, family farming sector within a market economy. To this end, Government has: removed limits on agriculture land ownership; enacted legislation for the sale or lease of state-owned land and supported the development of institutions to implement this policy; legislated the sale of former socially-owned enterprises; ceased the use of subsidized credit through the National Bank of Croatia - which previously represented 80% of direct State transfers to agriculture; reduced budget expenditures to the sector to some 3 % of government expenditures; and reduced the use of quotas to control foreign trade. The commitment to the private, family farm sector is reflected in Government's "Agricultural Policy Strategy" which was approved by Parliament in March 1995. The Farmer Support Services Project (FSSP) would be fully compatible with and support the implementation of Government's "Agriculture Policy Strategy". B. BANK'S COUNTRY ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 1.4 Private sector development is the focal point of the Bank's assistance to Croatia, and is a key element in the development of the agriculture sector. The proposed project would support the reform agenda outlined in the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy, discussed on April 20, 1995, by fostering
 private sector led growth in agriculture. The project would help Government establish essential public and private services to support the development of a private, mostly family-based agriculture sector. Other relevant issues, such privatization of former social sector farms and state-owned land, and trade and price policies are being handled under a proposed Agriculture Sector Adjustment Loan operation, currently under preparation. A proposed Rural Finance Pilot Project would support rural investments by facilitating farmers' links with the national financial network. The project is, therefore, one important element of a broader assistance strategy to the agriculture sector in Croatia, the combined effect of which would lead the way to a market-based, largely privately owned and operated agriculture sector in Croatia's reformed economy. C. RATiONALE FOR WORLD BANK INVOLVEMENT 1.5 This relatively modest project offers the opportunity to assist government in redefining its role in the agricultural sector, in developing policy analysis capacity, and in laying the foundation, through a range of limited programs, for the development of a mix of private and public agricultural support services which are accountable and responsive to the needs of the private fanner. With the break-up and privatization of large social sector farms and agro-processing units, traditional sources of support services for private farmers, such as provision of farm advice, extension services, and applied agriculture research are disappearing. Other services such as veterinary services, seed regulations, agriculture policies and statistics are in need of restructuring. The project would help fill this gap by supporting, through contracting out to the private sector wherever feasible, more efficient extension services, agricultural research and other services essential to the development of a modem, private agriculture sector. 1.6 Investment in support of private agriculture production is also shown to be indicated on economic, social and technical grounds. Growth in agriculture is crucial to support economic growth, and well within the realm of technical feasibility. Much of the known technology could be applied or easily adapted to meet private farmer needs. The project would also contribute to improving living standards in rural areas in which small-scale agriculture is a major employer and source of income.
 -3 - CHAPTER II. THE AGRICULTURE SECTOR A. AGRICULTURE IN THE ECONOMY 2.1 Agriculture is an important sector of the Croatian economy. The share of primary agriculture (including fisheries) in GDP increased from 10.0 percent in 1990 to 14.6 percent in 1992, mainly as a result of the fall in industrial production. With food processing included, the sectors share amounts to some 24 percent of GDP. The agriculture sector (including fisheries and food processing) employs some 15 percent of the active population. Some 41 percent of Croatia's population lives in rural areas. 2.2 Exports of agricultural and fisheries products have increased, both in absolute and relative terms. Between 1991 and 1994 agriculture exports increased by some 44 percent from roughly US$340 million to roughly US$490 million. As a share of the country's exports, it increased from some 9 percent to 12 percent during the same period. Imports during the same period fell from around US$560 million in 1991 to US$440 million in 1994, while the share of agriculture commodities and processed food in the country's total imports remained stable around 11 percent. Hence, in 1994 the agricultural sector had a modest trade surplus. 2.3 Levels of employment in agriculture have been more resilient than other sectors in the economy. From 1990 to 1993, employment in agriculture fell by 25 percent, compared with a fall of 50 percent for the rest of the economy. This is associated with the fall in GDP and the absence of employment in other branches of the economy. Agriculture has, therefore, been able to provide a buffer during a difficult economic and social adjustment period. 2.4 Agriculture is likely to play an increasingly supportive role in the development of tourism, in terms of supplying the increased demand for agricultural products (especially for fruits and vegetables in the vicinity of the Adriatic coast), and services in terms of specialized forms of tourism such as farmhouse tourism or hunting and fishing. B. NATURAL RESOURCE BASE 2.5 Croatia covers an area of about 56,750 km2 or 5,675,000 ha, of which 3,230,000 ha are agriculture land and 2,030,000 ha is arable land. Croatia has 2,028 km of land boundaries with other states. It is bounded to the west by the Adriatic Sea, to the northwest by Slovenia, to the northeast by Hungary, to the east by the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and to the south by Bosnia-Herzegovina. There are three main physiographic regions in the country: the Adriatic region to the west (32 percent of Croatian territory); the mountainous region in the center (12 percent); and the Pannonian region in the east (56 percent). 2.6 The coastal area, its hinterland and islands have a Mediterranean climate with mild wet winters and warm dry summers although some rain does fall in every month of the year. In the central mountain region the climate is affected to some extent by the altitude but otherwise this region is ameliorated by the Mediterranean climate of the coast and the continental type climate farther east. Eastern Croatia, or the Pannonian region has a continental climate with cold winters and hot summers although here again there is some rain in the sunmmer period, often falling in the form of thunderstorms.
 -4 - 2.7 Croatia has some 1.2 million hectares of grassland of which 0.4 million ha are meadows' and 800,000 million ha are pastures. Grasslands thus occupy about 40 percent of all agricultural land but the proportion of grass to arable varies greatly among regions and agroecological zones. Pasture yields are very low and average less than 1.0 mt/ha. Low production can be attributed in part to the neglect of these areas as a resource in favor of intensive systems of grain-based animal production by the former socialist regime. Meadows and pasture land usually occupy poorer quality land. C. THE SOCIAL SETTING 2.8 Croatia's population is estimated at 4.78 million. The 1990 household consumption survey estimated a total of 1.35 million households, of which 96,724 were classified as purely farming households and 404,355 were mixed households deriving part of their income from agriculture. Some 58 percent of the economically active farmers are 50 years of age or older. 2.9 Ex-social sector farms employ about 40,000 people, cultivates some 37 percent of all agriculture land (1.2 million ha) of which 22 percent is arable land (430,000 ha), 20 percent of the total cattle and 30 percent of the national pig population. In most cases 50 percent of the assets of these agro-kombinats, excluding land, has been transferred to employees and local civil servants, the remaining assets having been transferred to the State. It is rare for privatization of agricultural firms to have proceeded further. The State currently owns the lands of these farms and the land de-nationalization process, though legislated, is stalled. The lands are used under temporary, informal rental arrangements, mostly by the ex-social sector farms, often without payments being made to the State. D. FARM STRucTuRE 2.10 Croatia's agriculture is marked by a dual farm structure, consisting of numerous small private family farms on the one hand and some 500 large, vertically integrated agrokombinats (AKs) which have dominated the sector during the socialist period. The average farm size of Croatia's roughly 500,000 private farms is 2.9 ha of arable land consisting of about eight usually non-contiguous plots. Moreover, 33% of these farms are under one hectare in area and only 2.6 percent are more than 10 ha, though, more farmers operate enterprises in excess of 10 ha, usually through annual lease agreements. 2.11 Private farmers own about 63 percent of all agriculture land (2 million ha) and 78 percent (1.6 million ha) of arable land. The private fanrning structure essentially falls into two classes: some 400,000 part-time farmers and around 100,000 full-time farmers. First, the part-time farmers often operate on a sub-subsistence unit of less than 3 ha and with a growing labor constraint due to age. These aged farmers rent out land, but under the current land policy would not sell, as their land provides security. These farms will gradually be absorbed by the progressive farmers who already form the production core of the future. The rate of demise of these units will depend on what security and incentives Government policies will provide to encourage land transfers. 2.12 Second, the professional full-time private farmers (some 100,000 households) who own from 3 to 10 ha and rent extra land on an annual basis. These farms are generally profitable and often have three generations working. Despite the lack of technical and financial support, there is a confidence in the future of private farming as a profitable venture and as an active export prospect.  -5- farming predominates with farm sales mostly from grain, horticulture, and livestock products. Farms are often over-mechanized but, with a rapid growth in contracting services, utilization of equipment is improving. In the absence of land purchase possibilities and a mistrust of the banking system, tractors are considered a safe placement of possible surplus funds. A recent survey based on progressive full-time farmers showed that about 60 percent of full-time farmers own between 5 and 20 ha and 34% had holdings of less than 5 ha, being mostly in the Mediterranean intensive cropping area. 2.13 The 500 agro-kombinats (AK), often vertically integrated enterprises that not only farm but also own processing and marketing industries (as well as in addition some 86 agriculture cooperatives) dominated the agriculture sector during the socialist regime. The AKs were the main source of food production and received virtually all financial assistance to the agriculture sector to support maximization of production with little consideration of costs involved. The AKs held the most productive land but, through inappropriate methods of production, particularly cultivation practices, degradation of the soils has taken place and yields have been declining. In a market economy, and with progressive withdrawal of Government finance, the AK system has come under severe financial and operational pressures and now presents a formidable problem as to what procedures should be instituted to return the land and other assets to profitable farming systems. The AKs were also set up as a product procurement, storage and processing bases. E. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION 2.14 Land use is marked by the following features: the predominance of both agricultural land and, particularly, arable land in the private sector; the extensive areas of meadows and pasture with ownership of the latter dominated by the ex-social sector; private sector predominance in the viticulture and horticulture industries; and, the relative importance of cereal and industrial crop (oilseed, sugar beet) as opposed to fodder production for a predominantly continental climate. 2.15 Maize is by far the dominant crop in terms of area, followed by wheat which is the second most important crop. Barley ranks a poor third among the cereals and there are smaller areas of rye and other cereals. Potatoes predominate amongst the non-cereal crops, averaging 60,000-80,000 ha per year and are followed in importance in terms of area by sugar beet, soybeans and sunflower. Orchards occupy about 70,000 ha while vineyards cover almost 75,000 ha. Fodder crops are grown on about 172,000 ha and there are just over 400,000 ha of meadows. Crop yields in the ex-social sector often surpassed those of the private sector. Better access to credit and hence inputs favored social production, but the social sector orientation of maximizing production rather than profit was an important contributory factor. This is best demonstrated by comparing wheat yields, a crop sold mostly to the State, where ex-social sector farms yielded as much as 70 percent higher than private farms. The latter's maize, however, typically used for feeding livestock on-farm, out yields the former by more than 50 percent. 2.16 Livestock numbers decreased between 1961 and 1990. The population decrease has generally been accompanied by a progressive improvement in productivity per head in most sectors. Predominantly privately owned, 1989 data on herd and flock size in the private sector show about half of private farmers owned cattle but only about 4 percent had more than five cows, 52 percent kept pigs with only roughly 5 percent having five or more sows, and eight percent kept sheep with about 3 percent owning more than 20 head. By far the largest numbers of cattle, pigs and sheep are kept on average size farms of about 3 ha, but an increasing number of more commercially viable livestock farming units are emerging in the private sector.
 -6- F. SECTORAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 2.17 Due to the legacy of the past regime, the development of the agriculture sector is presently hampered by major constraints which Government is currently striving to address. These include: (1) changes in agriculture structures in terms of privatization of agro-kombinats and agro-processing companies, and in terms of land policy and privatization of agriculture land; (2) rural finance; (3) price and trade policy reform; and (4) farm support services. 2.18 Structural changes to be introduced in the sector include (i) the further privatization of the now semi-public assets owned by the agro-kombinats, (ii) the privatization of land (some 37 percent of the total agriculture land) of these ex-social sector farms which is presently Government owned and is currently farmed under short-term lease arrangements, either by the agro-kombinats or by private farmers; (iii) the privatization of the remaining publicly owned agro-processing entities; and (iv) the development of a land policy which would include the modernization of the cadastre system. The majority of land (some 63 percent) is, however, under private ownership allowing private farmers to produce and to provide a supply response to the services introduced under the project; the issue of land privatization relates to the 37 percent of the agriculture land under state ownership and agrokombinat management that would be addressed through a possible agriculture adjustment operation. 2.19 Further changes in the sector would also lead to increased competition in commodity and factor markets. Government is considering an Agriculture Sector Adjustment Loan (ASAL) with assistance of the Bank in order to address the privatization question of agro-kombinats and agro-processors as well as land related issues. Marketing, however, is not a major constraint to the success of the proposed project, because (i) most farmers at present manage to dispose of their production, even though marketing channels are not very sophisticated in Croatia, and (ii) agriculture inputs are generally available to farmers by a fairly broad range of input suppliers. Nevertheless, the project would assist in introducing market transparency and competition through a limited market information system monitoring sales at selected central points. Given the sometimes disappointing track record in the public support to marketing development it is not suggested to add such further activities to the agenda of the FSSP. In order to increase marketing infrastructure in the country MAF is currently discussing with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) the possibility of financing wholesale markets in the vicinity of Zagreb and other major towns in Croatia. 2.20 Rural Finance. Government perceives the lack of access to rural finance services as a major obstacle to significant renewed investment in the sector, and is concerned that this problem could ultimately constrain private farm productivity. MAF has requested the Bank to support a Line of Credit (LoC) to be channeled through selected commercial banks on a pilot basis in order to test effective demand and to overcome market failures associated with formal bank lending to the emerging private farm sector. The Bank is considering such a LoC under a separate Rural Finance Pilot Project. In general, however, farmers have reasonable scope to improve their operations, and introduce efficiency gains (e.g. fertilizer and animal feeding regime, crop and farm management) without the need for incremental external finance through farmers own internal cash generations and retained earnings as observed during numerous farm visits and consistently shown by farm models. Further development, however, should be supported through the provision of long-term financing of on-farm investments as envisaged under a possible Rural Finance Pilot Project. 2.21 Trade and Price Regime. The overall incentive structure has improved markedly over the past years and is likely to continue to evolve in the direction of border pricing indicating the true opportunity costs of resources to producers. Nevertheless, some issues persist in the field of pricing policies (e.g.,
 -7 - some import quotas, and some floor prices). During the last years of the Yugoslav Federation the policy environment was characterized by price policies with far-reaching intervention on both the production and the consumption side, a trade regime based almost exclusively on import and export quotas, and a subsidy policy pursuing cheap finance through broad interest rate subsidies. The highly distorted incentive framework of the past was almost exclusively geared towards the support of social enterprises and agro- kombinats. 2.22 In recent years Croatia's agriculture incentive environment has undergone important change towards a more market-based incentive system. Consumer prices have been completely liberalized. Import quotas on many products have been removed and replaced with tariffs. The application for membership in the GATT / WTO, which has been recently submitted, will spur these changes. On the macro side, rampant inflation has been brought to a halt through tight monetary and fiscal policies. Independence and the war have led to a dramatic cut in the agricultural budget, from roughly DM360 million in 1990 to about DM140 million in 1994 which corresponds to a share of 2.6 percent of total government expenditures compared to 15.0 percent in 1990. Substantial changes have also occurred in the allocation of this budget. A huge interest rate subsidy was the dominant form of direct farm support during 1991 - 1993 (on average DM150 million annually or 80 percent of the budget). These interest rate subsidies were discontinued at the end of 1993. 2.23 Croatia's agriculture policy has moved steadily towards the model of more liberalized economies since the 1980s. Price support to most farm commodities is modest, and much lower than equivalent levels of support in the EU, with the exception of sugar. Part of this support comes directly from modest allocations of public funds, while most is provided implicitly through the trade regime. The range of commodities supported has been considerably reduced over the years, and now includes only those considered by Government to be strategically important, such as sugar, wheat, maize and milk. Prices for commodities such as fruit, vegetables, meat and other dairy products are determined by market forces. Some quotas, though significantly reduced over the past years, remain on sugar, wheat, seed and fertilizer imports, in particular. Changes of trade and price policies would involve a revision of the operations of the State Directorate for Commodity Reserves. 2.24 Table 1 below shows nominal protection coefficients for selected agricultural commodities. Current price and trade policies result in low protection for oilseeds and pork, moderate protection for cereals and milk and very high trade protection for sugarbeets. Beef, on the contrary, is not protected. Moderate levels of support for farmers have been retained; most of the support directed to agriculture accrues, however, to agricultural industries rather than farmers. Private farming historically has been and continues to be associated with the commodities for which the least protection was granted and the least price distortions introduced (i.e., horticulture, and animal production, in particular, meat, and to a lesser extent, milk for which protection is moderate). The social farm sector has typically specialized in wheat and maize grain production, and in sugar. While the level of protection associated with maize grain has been moderately high, most maize produced by private farmers is not marketed but fed on-farm to cattle and pigs (i.e., products without important price distortions). Price policies for wheat, which is also grown by private farmers, is presently driven by strategic considerations, and likely to change to a more rational policy, once hostilities cease in the region.

It is anticipated that under the planned ASAL further alignment of domestic input and commodity prices with border price levels would be supported. 2.26 Support services to agriculture have, in the past, been geared to the agro-kombinats and farm cooperatives. No support services have been directly available to the private farming community in terms of extension, applied research, or animal breeding services; veterinary services have, in the past, been oriented towards social sector agriculture. The seed industry has been left without a regulatory framework which would enhance private sector participation in seed multiplication and export; agriculture statistics and the policy formulating capacities of MAF have not been developed under the former Yugoslavia. The thrust of the FSSP is on improving these services in the short term. 2.27 Agriculture technology is generally inefficient when judged, not only by European standards, but also by those of elite farmers within Croatia. Efficiency gains in production are available in fertilizer use, land preparation, crop sowing, crop rotations, and animal feeding, provided the research/extension system is enabled to respond to farmers' perceived needs. 2.28 Combined, these partly historic constraints continue to curtail the development of commercially viable family farms in Croatia. In the short term, private agriculture could be substantially supported and the framework for major structural reforms established through a process of institutional restructuring leading to increased client accountability and ownership.

GOVERNMENT'S AGRIcuLTURE DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY 2.29 Through it's "Agriculture Policy Strategy" approved by Parliament in March 1995, Government has made a clear commitment to promote the development of private farming within the framework of a market economy. The objective of Government's agriculture policy is to promote efficiency in production and marketing, and ensure the competitiveness of the agriculture sector on world markets. The aim is also to overcome the legacy of large scale kombinats by giving emphasis to the development of private family farms. This would be achieved by further restructuring of the current system of direct support to agriculture production from the budget; replacement of import quotas with tariffs; and reduction of tariffs under GATT's developing country status. Policy actions would also include the introduction of structural changes in land and asset ownership by the full privatization of former social sector farms and land, and of publicly owned agroprocessing enterprises; improving rural financial services on a sustainable basis using both commercial banks and public institutions; tariffication of remaining import quotas and strictly limiting the commodities for which limited support will be provided; development of farm support services; and social policies including the reconstruction of war damaged areas and restructuring of the agriculture pension fund. 2.30 The provision of relevant support services to the private farming community is a key instrument of MAF's strategy. The need to establish a relevant agriculture knowledge system which would explicitly allow for participation of the local farming communities, and combine private and public sector elements in the provision of extension services is clearly recognized. Improving the regulatory framework of the seed industry, as well as the veterinary services in terms of epidemiological analysis and monitoring, has also been stressed by MAF as being an important public service. MAF also recognizes the potential of the country's grassland resources which so far have been under utilized. Policy decision-makers are, furthermore, aware of the need to improve the empirical basis and analytical methods in formulating policies. These support services are recognized to have many characteristics of public goods, hence justifying the public provision of such services.
 - 10- CHAPTER III. ISSUES IN AGRICULTURE SUPPORT SERVICES A. AGRICULTURE EXTENSION AND APPLIED RESEARCH 3.1 Private farming enjoyed government support in the former Yugoslavia only to the extent that it benefitted the social or cooperative agro-industrial subsectors. Agricultural technology development was focused on large scale farming and production maximization, paying insufficient heed to profitability and economic sustainability. While some private farmers adapted this technology to meet their needs, most learned and applied technology which is now widely recognized as being inappropriate to a market economy. Although a body of appropriate technology exists and more can be gleaned from the practices of successful private farmers, there remains the need to restructure and reorient the agriculture knowledge system, comprising agriculture extension and applied research. This includes redefining its present mandate and structure, giving it a market focus, making it responsive and accountable to its clients and financiers and ensuring its future financial sustainability. While public institutions and investment will be required to initiate the process, the medium term objective will be the progressive transfer of management and financial responsibility for agricultural knowledge services to the private agricultural sector. 3.2 Improved technology would enable farmers to increase production efficiency, reduce costs, increase yield, improve quality and diversify production. Both public and private benefit would ensue, the latter already in evidence amongst a core group of elite farmers. Instruments to support technology promotion are presently limited. The main sources of information available to farmers are a small but competent rural press, ill-trained Zupanija-based2 advisors, some elements of the scientific community, a recently privatized veterinary service and a small, under-resourced national extension service. These poorly wedded extension elements generally lack market or farm management focus, are short on appropriate technology and, in the public sector, are largely unaccountable to their farmer clients. A stimulus is required which would engage the farmer in constraint analysis and technology development, better employ the public and private extension resources to address identified needs, increase client accountability, and ultimately, transfer responsibility for the delivery of technical advice to the private sector. In a similar way, agriculture research lacks relevance and accountability to the farming community. All agriculture research is under the responsibility of the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), and only modestly funded at a level equivalent to roughly 0.2 percent of agriculture GDP. A detailed description of issues are provided in Annex H (Agriculture Extension) and Annex J (Agriculture Research) of the Supplemental Volume. The project would strengthen the agriculture knowledge system by developing public and private extension services and by restructuring applied research management through a competitive grant based research system. Given the broadly public goods nature of these services, no cost recovery is envisaged during project implementation. B. ANIMAL PRODUCTION SUPPORT SERVICES 3.3 Livestock production in Croatia is mainly a private sector enterprise. Animal output provides 40 percent of agricultural GDP. Support services have historically been provided through the government veterinary service, and public sector breeding enterprises which require reform in order to be relevant in a private farming context. Clinical veterinary services have recently been privatized and some of the public functions of disease surveillance and vaccination are now carried out under contract from MAF by private veterinary stations; however, competition in the provision of veterinary services is still limited through regional monopolies granted to the newly private veterinary stations. Insufficient epidemiological 2/ Zupanija is the Croatian word for district.
 - 11 - disease control and monitoring has resulted in import bans to key markets in the EU. A new Law on Veterinary Services is currently being drafted. The draft version of the new law on veterinary services has been selectively reviewed and assurances were received that (i) the new veterinary law, when promulgated, will remove constraints to competition in the provision of animal breeding and veterinary services, in particular, that regional monopolies for veterinary services would be abolished, and that the prices for clinical veterinary services were subject to a negotiation process between veterinarians and farmers or their respective representatives; and (ii) animal semen importation is unconstrained outside of normal quarantine requirements. 3.4 Livestock production has been largely based on housed animals fed mainly concentrates, in production systems focused on maximum per animal production rather than on optimum profitability within a sustainable system context. This grain-based feeding largely ignores the comparative advantage Croatia has through its largely under-utilized grassland and pasture resources (some 1.2 million ha). The project would improve animal health services, assist in the development of the grassland potential, and introduce private sector breeding-related activities on a pilot scale. (See also Annex J, Animal Health Support Services, and Annex K, Pasture and Forage Development, Supplemental Volume). C. SEED INDUSTRY 3.5 The Croatian seed industry has considerable potential but is constrained by an inadequate regulatory framework, particularly the lack of Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation, and deficiencies in the present seed legislation. With no statutory authority to regulate the industry and a lack of transparency in the testing process (including failure to enforce regulations) international suppliers are deterred from entering the market. Importation quotas are a further constraint. This results in absence of competition in the provision of plant genetic materials to the farming community, and foregone seed export possibilities. The project would support the development of the regulatory and institutional framework within which a private sector seed industry could operate efficiently. (See also Annex L, Seed Industry Development, Supplemental Volume). D. MARKET INFORMATION SYSTEM AND AGRICULTURE STATISTICS 3.6 Prior to independence, the collection of agricultural statistics was oriented towards production on ex-social sector farms. The consequent lack of information on private farms has become a serious constraint to policy analysis, especially following the adoption of a new Agricultural Policy Strategy which emphasizes the role of family farms. It is difficult to respond effectively to the needs of Croatia's small-scale family farms when so little is known about the constraints they face and the implications of policy changes for their well-being. Collection and access to timely and relevant agriculture market and price information is also deficient. The project would support the establishment of a modest market information system, and of regular on-farm monitoring surveys. E. POLICY FORMULATION CAPABILITIES 3.7 Adoption of the Agricultural Policy Strategy has paved the way for widespread policy reform over the next 2-3 years. The MAF's capacity for policy analysis and policy formation is limited however, both in available staff and skills. Given the upcoming GATT / WTO membership negotiations and the possible discussions on EU Association Agreements, price and trade policy formulation capabilities are recognized as being of the highest priority. The project would strengthen MAF's policy formulation capabilities. (See also Annex M, The Policy Analysis Unit: Background and Scope of Work, Supplemental Volume).

PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND CONCEPT 4.1 The project would support the GOC's agricultural policy by efficiently providing technology- related support services that are relevant to the private farmers. The aim is to improve the income of the private farming community and increase its productivity and hence the competitiveness of the sector. The project would address the need: (i) to change delivery mechanisms for the provision of technical services to the private farming community and (ii) for institutional restructuring to meet the needs of a market economy. It would allow public authorities to respond to the service needs of the private farming community and to ensure that private agriculture and agribusiness irrevocably have a voice in the formulation of agricultural services and support policies. 4.2 The activities pursued under the project aim to have a major impact on private farming in the short term and to introduce significant institutional improvements in the medium term. Increased farmer ownership and accountability of the agricultural knowledge system (i.e., extension and applied research) are an essential element of project design. The provision of relevant and efficient veterinary services and support for the shift from a grain-based animal production system to a lower cost pasture-based livestock industry are other central objectives. Rationalizing the regulatory framework for the seed industry would also be supported. The project would furthermore seek to strengthen MAF's policy formulation capabilities and the agriculture data base in order to ensure more rational policy decisions in the future. No support would be provided to the ex-social sector Agro-Kombinats under the project (with the exception of the research divisions of the AKs who would be eligible to participate in the competitive research grant system (see para 4.15)). BENEFITS 6.1 Private farmers will be the principal beneficiaries, deriving advantage from inproved production technology and animal health services, and a strengthened regulatory framework for the seeds industry and from government policies and services more conducive to the development of a vigorous private agricultural sector. The project would contribute to improving living standards in rural areas in which small-scale agriculture is a major employer and source of income. The project would also contribute to increased productivity and production, as well as to an improved domestic food supply. Adaptive and applied research would initially be focused on areas yielding quick returns, as part of a confidence building process for the farming community and the extension and research services. Improved production efficiency through better soil and crop management and crop rotations, and improved agro-chemical use in the cropping sector; and improved returns from dairy and sheep production through better nutrition and health care are likely early outcomes. Private farm advisors and public extension staff, trained in financial and farm management principals, would assist farmers in making more rational investment decisions. The investment will also generate substantial public benefits: disease control and livestock product sanitary inspection will improve, and improved agricultural production and policy is likely to lead to better resource utilization. 6.2 Improved Support Services. Farmers would have access to advisory services in which they have ownership - the cost partly shared with Government - that are better able to respond, both quantitatively and qualitatively, to needs and opportunities. Public extension and research staff would be more accountable to farmers and adequately resourced, both materially and conceptually, to meet the demands of the emerging commercial family farms. Staff motivation is also expected to improve. 6.3 Institutional Reforms. The process of resource transfer in the agricultural knowledge system from wholly public to a partnership of farmers and agri-business will be initiated leading to a longer-term possibility for public and private sector cooperation. The capacity to deliver timely, accurate market and sectoral information will be improved. Increased Farm Incomes (see Annex E) 6.4 Quantifying the incremental impact of the broad range of project activities which to a large extent are of an institutional development nature is notoriously difficult, given the numerous non-service factors influencing decision-making at the farm level. General research indicates that economic returns to investments in agriculture research and extesnion as well as in other services can be very high. As an approximation, indicative financial and economic farm models have been prepared to assess the likely impact of project activities at the farm level. Farm models across the main agro-ecological zones of the country and representing major production systems are presented in Annex E (and N of the Supplemental Volume). The models are indicative and it is believed that they reflect changes which are likely to occur on farms which are exposed to more focused extension services and have access to improved management advice, seed, livestock and other inputs. 6.5 The crop and livestock budgets which form the basis of each farm/household model were prepared in consultation with local agronomists and economists and checked by field discussion with farmers, where possible. Generally they postulate crop yield increases of about 15 percent with project and include higher fertilizer, better seed inputs and improved livestock rations. Farm size has been held constant between without and with project situations, although there are changes in cropping patterns with project. The investments to expand farm size, buy additional machinery or livestock or to install
 - 28 - irrigation, are excluded from these models as currently medium to short term credit is not available to farmers. Model farm size is typically in the range of 5 to 7 ha (except for the intensive Dalmatia Vegetable model). This is a little larger than average private farm size in these regions but there are many such farms and it is considered that they are likely to respond first to improved support services. Labor budgets show substantial annual surpluses of family labor in all models, without and with project. Seasonal peaks in labor demand require use of hired labor in the intensive vegetable models and most models do require incremental family labor with project. Household consumption of farm produce has been included in each model and meets staple grain, milk, egg and meat needs in most cases (with the exception of the high value vegetable model). Farm families will have to draw upon the cash surpluses shown in each model to cover other food and living expenses. Overhead costs are also included in each model to cover business expenses not readily allocated to individual crop or livestock enterprises. Such costs are mostly in the range US$1,450 to US$1,800 per farm and cover electricity, other fuel, land tax and insurance, tractor and equipment services and labor, not related to individual crop activities. 6.6 As very few private farms in Croatia have access to short or long term credit, the financing of production inputs in these models follows reality as in both without and with project situations 100 percent of operating costs are financed by retained farm earnings from the previous year. Incremental production costs typically lie in the range of US$715 to US$2,200 per farm, or a little under half of the expected gross value of incremental revenue. This is within the capacity of most model farms to finance, either from without project retained earnings, from off-farm income, or by moving to the with project situation in steps phased over two or three years. Each model attempts to meet it's livestock feed needs from on-farm forage and crop production, in line with usual practice in Croatia. The nature of much of the new technology proposed is such (better seeds, additional fertilizer) that it is likely to be accepted promptly when the benefits are demonstrated clearly. 6.7 Financial analysis of the five models (see Table 7) indicates that: (i) project activities are likely to yield sufficient incremental financial benefit to farmers to encourage them to participate in or actively use better extension, animal health services, seeds and market information (on average returns of 45 percent, ranging from 8 to 92 percent over the without project situation; (ii) in most of the models farmers clearly have the ability to fund incremental short term inputs from internal cash generation, e.g.: monthly milk payments or pig sales. In the Istrian model it may be necessary for farmers to fund the added inputs from off-farm work in the tourist industry or by phasing changes suggested in the model over several years; (iii) switching values (see Annex E and N) indicate that the models are robust, requiring an increase of more than 100 percent in operating costs or a fall of more than 50 per cent in incremental inflows to reduce NPV to zero at 10 percent discount rate; (iv) financial benefits may be earned through changes in cropping pattern or livestock processing/marketing as well as increased technical efficiency; (v) there is a substantial surplus of farm labor available on the modelled farms, and labor returns per hour are maintained or increased under the with-project scenario for each model; (vi) farmers have an ability to pay for useful services, especially where the scale of operation is large enough to cover overheads and basic living costs or where high value vegetable, cheese or similar products are involved.

RISKS 6.11 The potential resistance at the operational level by the various Government institutions and services involved in the project to give up traditional influence and responsibilities following their reorganization is a risk associated with the project. This would be addressed through a substantial training program for the staff of these institutions with a focus on farm community participation and on the rationale for the changes introduced under the project. Associated to this is the risk of a slow establishment of an Agriculture Research Council and a National Seed Authority. This is being addressed through considerable technical assistance provided both during pre-project start-up using Japanese grant
 - 31 - funds, and during early project implementation to work out procedures and to assist these nascent institutions. A second risk lies in the number and size of procurement contracts to be implemented during the first project years; to mitigate a procurement specialist has been hired prior to Loan Effectivness to compile the major packages to be procured during the first project year. A third risk during implementation stems from limited farmer capacity to form and support private associations, and the potential limitations of extension and research staff to evolve with the market economy. This risk will be counteracted by project activities which will focus technology development on efficiency increases, improved farm management practices and product diversification; the assurance of unequivocal Government support to farmer associations and farmer guided extension and research services; and a focus of project design on farm community participation. C. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT 6.12 The project has been placed in the environmental Category B. An Environmental Analysis (EA) under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank has been carried out by an independent commission appointed by MAF. The EA (Annex F) concludes: (i) no significant negative environmental impacts associated with project implementation are to be expected; (ii) while private agriculture production is likely to intensify, albeit from a low base, the intensity of the social sector production is likely to decrease; and (iii) by the nature of the various project activities, in particular, extension and applied research, agricultural practices would become environmentally safer. The EA also presents an inventory of major environmental legislation relevant for the agriculture sector and concludes that while a whole body of relevant environmental legislation has developed, enforcement has scope for improvement. The EA underlines that project implementation would act as a catalyst to the further development of environmental legislation and improved enforcement. Registration of agrochemicals and development of Integrated Pest Management would be strengthened under the NSA (see para. 4.25). 6.13 No special mitigation plan has been required by the EA as no negative environmental impact is directly caused by the project.; emphasis has been put on the extension services to provide guidance to private farmers on the appropriate use of agro-chemicals. To support the concept of sustainable agriculture and appropriate handling of agrochemicals, agreement will be sought during negotiations with the Borrower, that MAF would develop environmental ('best practice') guidelines for its extension service. These guidelines would give orientation to farmers on the safe and proper use of agro-chemicals at the latest by April 30, 1997 as a dated covenant to the Loan agreement (see para. 7.1).

The project would be implemented over a period of four years (CY96-99) after a period of intensive pre-project activities in CY95 financed under a Japanese Grant. Prior to project effectiveness major packages for procurement during the first year of implementation would be compiled. 2. Overall Project Implementation. The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry MAF would take overall responsibility for project implementation, and direct responsibility for the implementation of the agricultural extension and applied research components, for the policy analysis support component, and for the veterinary epidemiological activities. 3. Extension. The Deputy Minister Extension would take responsibility for implementing the agriculture extension program. The extension service, which has its own budget and permanent staff, would operate 21 Zupanija Extension Service Centers under the supervision of MAF. The broad functions of the extension staff at headquarters would consist of: developing the diagnostic survey methodology; supporting the national research prioritization process; facilitating research extension linkages; organizing skill-gap based extension staff training; ensuring technical and market information flows; and developing the mass media communication programs. 4. The ZESCs would be staffed with 4 to 5 extension specialists in each of the 21 Zupanijas (no incremental staff required). They would work through and support the creation of farmer groups, private consultants and agro-industry and conduct on-farm demonstrations and mass media communications. The ZESCs would be guided by local Advisory Committees with a broad representation of private farmers in the Zupanija. Initially such farmer advisory committees would be formed with the assistance of the ZESCs on an ad-hoc basis (in cooperation with the local chapters of the Croatian Farmers Association). More formal procedures would be developed through the Advisory Committees once established. 5. Some 45 local farmers associations would be supported through the project. Local farmers associations interested in employing private advisors would be eligible for project grant funds through MAF on a matching basis to pay for the salary of the advisor. Public support to fund a private farm advisor salary would be based on the following formula: 80 percent of gross salary in year 1, 50 percent in year 2, 35 percent in year 3, and 25 percent in year 4. No support would be provided thereafter. The balance would be provided by the farmer group. Associations would recruit suitably qualified advisors under a standard 4 year contract with a 6 month probation period. Association and consultant compliance with the contract conditions would be closely monitored by the ZESCs. Individual private consultants would be eligible to only one support package over the project life. The roughly 45 groups under the farmer-based milk recording scheme would be established in three selected Zupanija by the herd recording staff of the Croatian Livestock Selection Center (CLSC).

The trainers would subsequently implement a retraining program for extension staff at all levels including both headquarters and Zupanija, organized by the training coordinator appointed to the headquarters of the Extension Department. Each three-four week training program would be for about ten staff. This training would include practical field exercise. About 110 staff would be trained in this manner during the first two years of project implementation. Additional courses would be provided for scientific staff involved in adaptive research and for private extension advisors hired under the farmer group scheme. Regular and special in-service training programs for extension staff at all levels would also be introduced, organized by MAF's training coordinator. Overseas training would be provided for four extension managers. They would participate in short-term training programs in extension methodology with practical exposure to field operations in selected European countries. On return, the trainees would be required to hold a series of seminars for extension staff and be required to contribute to in-service staff training courses. 7. Research. The Deputy Minister Agriculture together with the project manager would coordinate the establishment of the Agricultural Research Council (ARC) and provide guidance to the ARC during project implementation. The ARC, responsible for the allocation of the national applied agriculture research budget, would be independent of MAF but answerable to the Minister of Agriculture and Forestry. MOST would be responsible for the general administration of applied research contracts; this would include screening research proposals, procurement of research equipment associated with the research contracts, and off-site and on-site supervision of research work. The establishment of the ARC as well as the formulation of the operating procedures would take place prior to project effectiveness with technical assistance funded under the Japanese Grant. 8. The project would support an applied agriculture research management system to produce relevant and timely information for the private family farmers. The establishment of an independent Agriculture Research Council (ARC) which would establish research policy and priorities for funding applied agriculture research would be key to ensuring relevance and timeliness of research to farmers. The ARC would consist of a majority of farmer representatives (9 members nominated from each of the nine agriculture regions); in addition, ARC would consist of one representative from MAF and MOST, respectively, three representatives from the research community, and one from agrobusiness. The Minister of Agriculture and Forestry would nominate the chairperson of the ARC. 9. Demand-driven research. The ARC would invite the scientific community (both public and private sector) on the basis of publicly announced Terms of Reference, to submit research proposals to the council, i.e. contracts for applied research would be demand driven. The research agenda would be (i) open-ended and determined by the ARC, and (ii) would allow for a broad scope of topics to be researched ranging from production technology to market research and development. Any bona fide Croatian research institution, public or private, would be eligible to participate under the competitive research grant system. The ARC shall make such rules and establish procedures as required openly to carry out its responsibility. The Council shall also promulgate procedures and select participants for external and internal training of scientific and faculty personnel supported under the project.. The Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) would carry out the technical and scientific review (involving national and foreign reviewers) of the submitted proposals and would submit to the ARC short lists of proposals in the respective areas of applied research for decision making. MOST would administer, supervise (including on-site supervision) and audit the research contracts. The ARC would be assisted by a small (one or two) person secretariat which would call the ARC meetings on the initiative of the Chairperson.
