 ANNEX A - 46 - Project Implementation Plan m. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR AGRICULTURE EXTENSION A. Rationale and Design of the Project 18. The four-year project must lay the foundation for the effective delivery of farner services and develop a momentum for the continuing development of new technology and farm management practices responsive to the needs of the private farmer. 19. With the development of land holding legislation and economic liberalization in general, farming in Croatia will rapidly change. These developments will press farmers to increase farm size, through acquisition or lease, and to change their production mix, as well as their production systems in response to price changes and new market opportunities. Among the factors that will stimulate change are: (i) the return of tourism to the Adriatic coast, which will expand the market for high quality, ecologically clean products; (ii) the growing awareness to environmental issues and to healthy food, and the realization that Croatia may have a comparative advantage in producing healthy food for the European market; and (iii) the low labor costs offers prospects for the development of labor-intensive production. 20. Low input techniques are more knowledge intensive, if they are to be reliable and profitable. Practicing a more rational use of inputs to maximize income, rather than yields, also requires fine tuning at farm level. The adaptation of Croatia's farmers to the new circumstances requires new skills, as well as closer links with scientists and technicians to develop these techniques. This link is provided through the extension services. 21. Given the uncertainties regarding the future of the social farms and cooperatives, and the continuing processes of economic restructuring, the short-term option is to improve the operational efficiency and effectiveness of the small state-financed extension service. However, a progression to a semi-privatized advisory service must be an objective and parallel development of private consultants would be supported through the project. Future private sector advisory services could emerge through farmer-owned cooperatives, commodity associations and agribusiness. Such initiatives would also be encouraged during project implementation. Progressively, farmers are expected to absorb an increasing share of the costs of their advisory services. 22. The current structure is being reorganized at all levels. At the Ministry level, a clear definition of responsibilities has been agreed, providing a direct line of communication between the extension service and the Ministry and the new Agriculture Research Council. The nucleus Zupanija Extension Support Centers (ZESCs) is being established and officers will have a career structure and salary scales, awarding for performance. 23. The farmers of Croatia are a heterogeneous group, and so are their advisory requirements. However, with the limited staffing resources available, it will not be possible to give cover to all farmers on a one-to-one basis. Knowledge on the present situation and performance of these farmers will be crucial to the design and extension strategies and activities. The current constraints on transport, equipment and extension aids will have to be addressed and the knowledge and skills mix of the extension service developed through a broad training program.
 Project Implementation Plan - 47 - ANNEX A 24. The future public extension service will have to operate within the limits of a severe budget constraint and care must be taken to control recurrent costs. These cost constraints will prevent any major increases in staff numbers, yet farmer contact must be increased, the operational efficiency must also be improved and the effective delivery of relevant packages given priority. The Zupanija Extension Support Center (ZESC) will therefore operate as the core resource center for the rural community. It should be guided by a Zupanija extension advisory committee with strong representation from the local farmer community, and operate on the basis of "client ownership". With limited staff resources, the ZESCs would have to operate through farmer groups and use production/ marketing/management associations as their primary contacts to the extent possible. 25. Extension support services to individual farmers would have to be built through the private sector, working in co-operation with the ZESCs and utilizing their technical resources. 26. The focus of the future program would be on increasing farmer incomes. In the short term this requires a thorough, critical review of past relevant research and where it can be applied, and also the identification of the improved practices of progressive farmers through farming systems analysis. The research program, conversely, would need to be devised jointly between scientists and producers to develop short-term action programs to develop appropriate technologies. The effective establishment of this linkage through a farmer guided extension service forms the main rationale of this component. B. Objectives and Strategies 27. The objective is to provide an extension system, within the existing fiscal, economic and social constraints, that helps the development of sustainable increases in private farm family income and well being. The extension service would aim do this by the provision of sound business management, marketing and technical advice and information to farmers and their families using the most effective and efficient communication procedures. 28. The component, as proposed, would link agricultural extension and research workers with farmers in the identification of production constraints and opportunities, and the development of appropriate strategies for their solution or exploitation. 29. More specifically, the objectives would be: (i) to generate information on the current systems used by farmers and to identify areas where improvements can be made; (ii) to improve the efficiency of technology transfer and improve the relevance of information to farmers' specific problems; (iii) to train and equip the extension service to adjust to the new economic environment; and (iv) to develop an operating mode conducive to building increased co-operation and participation between both public and private extension and research, and the farming community.
 ANNEX A - 48 - Project Implementation Plan C. Project Components 30. Support to Public Extension Services. Under the project the existing public Zupanija (district) extension offices (21 with a total staff of some 110) would develop into community supervised Zupanija Extension Service Centers (ZESC). These would provide the impetus to farmer group formation (see below) and act as a source of infonnation and specialized guidance to private advisers directly serving the farmers. The ZESC would be assisted through voluntary local Advisory Committees representing the local farming community and agro-business. Office, computer and teaching equipment, and vehicles would be made available to the ZESCs. 31. Detailed Features: Zupanija Extension Service Centers (ZESCs). The existing county extension centers (one in each of the 21 Zupanija) would be developed in to Zupanija Extension Service Centers (ZESCs) and consist of a professional team of 4-5 extension officers and one support staff, led by an extension coordinator. Each ZESC would be provided with two cars and mileage allowance for staff-owned cars. Provision is also made for office accommodation at the Zupanija headquarters including rentals, communication and office equipment supplies. Each would be provided with a set of office furniture, three personal computers, appropriate software, and a photocopier. Extension/communication equipment, including slide and overhead projectors, VDO and camera would be included. To support the development of ZESC activities, the project would provide funds for on-farm technology testing, publication of extension material, the production of a farm management handbook, and for subscriptions to magazines. 32. Diagnostic Survey. During early project implementation, each ZESC would carry out a one-time, farm community based diagnostic survey in order to develop a thorough understanding of the constraints and potential of the areas they are servicing, and to give the extension services the opportunity to inform farmers in their area of the new extension approach. The diagnostic survey exercise would help define the annual working program of the Zupanija extension service (a systematic working program, including monitorable performance indicators for the public extension services was developed in 1995 for the first time) MAF's extension department with TA provided under a Japanese Grant funding would develop a simple methodology to carry out these diagnostic surveys. 33. Private Extension Support. The formation of a limited number of farmer groups (some 45 groups, roughly 2 groups in each Zupanija) on a pilot basis would be supported in view of farmer groups employing private advisors in agricultural production, farm business management, and marketing associations management on a matching grant basis. Each group would directly employ its own adviser who would be funded by MAF during the first four years on a matching grant basis and receive some basic training equipment on a grant basis. The public extension service would develop standard contracts and provide the newly established farmer groups with legal advice during the process of hiring private advisors. 34. Detailed Features: Support to Farmers Associations. The project would encourage farmers to form self-help groups with a common interest in technology development, bulk supply of inputs, product marketing, or in sharing equipment, essentially by: (i) limiting time spent by the public extension officers
 Project Implementation Plan - 49 - ANNEX A with individual farmers and extending public extension efforts with farmer groups; (ii) offering legal and administrative information/advice on formal group formation; and (iii) providing technical and managerial training to group leaders. Such training would include both informal training, extended during visits or short seminars by zupanija staff, and formal training, which would be organized at national level and involve guest speakers from agribusiness. Private Sector Extension Services. The provision of private advisory services would be developed in conjunction with the establishment of farmer associations. Such associations would be eligible under the project to receive grants to directly hire on a full time basis qualified professional agricultural staff (many of which are presently with the public sector). It is anticipated that some 45 groups employing advisers be forned within the duration of the project. Grants would cover: (1) training in business, marketing and extension management.; (2) partial salary support for farmer association employing a private consultants over a four year period on a matching grant basis (based on the following matching grant formula: 80% in year 1, 50% in year 2, 35% in year 3, and 25 in year 4; no support would be provided thereafter; the balance would be provided by the farmer group) ; (3) provision of basic equipment (computer & printer etc.) to the farmer group. 35. Farmer-based Milk Recording Pilot Scheme. Also on a pilot basis, farmer herd recording groups (some 45 in three Zupanijas) would be supported through the Croatian Livestock Selection Center (CLSC) in close collaboration with the ZESC to promote farmer based milk recording. Milk recording data, an important management tool in milk and animal production would be used by the extension service and the farmer herd recording group. Farmer-based milk recording would also be a first step in supporting private animal breeding efforts and in reducing the high costs of animal performance recording presently carried out by the public sector. Project support would include milk production recording equipment, limited computer equipment, and industry staff training including a study tour to selected European animal breeding programs. 36. Training Program. A substantial training program, including: a trainers of trainer program; a one-time general staff orientation course; and regular and specialized in-service training, would be carried out to enable the staff of the extension service to acquire the skills necessary to operate under a changed mandate. Subjects would include farm business management, financial and marketing skills, group formation skills, preparation of mass media and training packages, and information management. The training of trainer program would be carried out prior to project start-up financed through a Japanese Grant. Limited study tours would also be carried out by selected extension experts to get a better understanding of extension issues and operations in other countries. Private advisors working under the farmer group pilot scheme would also participate in this training program. 37. Detailed Features: A Reorientation Training program would be supported by the project for all extension officers. The staff would undertake a short course designed to familiarize them with the role and activities of the extension service. The course would be conducted by senior extension staff who would themselves be trained through a eight week training course, designed and conducted by an internationally recruited consultant. This training of trainers would take place prior to project start-up. All other extension staff would receive their training within two years of the trainers being trained.
 ANNEX A - 50 - Project Implementation Plan The project would also support a Regular annual In-service Training program for extension service staff. Extension staff would participate in a one-week training course at the zonal level, designed to update their knowledge and skills, based on the extension themes for that particular year. A full-time training and staff development coordinator would be appointed at headquarters with the task of organizing these annual training programs and conducting skill-gap analysis for all staff. Additional Specialized Technical Training would be provided to extension staff in making the best use of mass media including radio, the press and TV and in technologies of production where skill gaps are identified. Training would be provided by specialists from Croatia and by internationally recruited consultants. Short-term Overseas Training would be supported for eight staff (4 agro-economists and 4 extension officers) for three months each at appropriate training institutions to gain experience in training organization, skill job analysis and extension methods and administration. 38. Mass Media Programs. Approximately 25 thematic training packages would be developed for use by Zupanija extension service staff and other advisers for incorporation within an extension program for farmers. The training packages would also form the basis of mass media activities which would be developed on a contractual basis involving the extension and research services. Topics would include farm business management, improving marketing arrangements of primary producers, and technical items such as integrated crop production and pest management. 39. Detailed Features: The extension service would introduce the use of mass media techniques in widening its farmer contact capacity. Professional producers (TV and radio) would be commissioned to prepare programs on specific themes being extended in collaboration with the extension and research services.. Content would be both technical or of general interest to the rural communities. An allowance of roughly US$430,000 has been included to cover the costs of production of about 25 programs over four years. 40. On-farm Trials and Demonstration: Farmer - Extension Research Link. A on-farm trial and demonstration program would be carried out through the ZESC in coordination with agriculture researchers perusing competitive grant-based applied research supported through the project (see para below). 41. Technical Assistance. Four areas of TA would be required during the life of the project: * three months consultancy for the training of trainers (which would be financed under the Japanese Grant Facility); * eleven months consultancy on extension methodology, adaptive research priorities, design and evaluation of trials; management and organization of an extension program, program monitoring and evaluation; * three months consultancy for special skills training amongst extension staff: audio-visual communication, farmer association organization, farm business management, financial and marketing skills, information management, trials and demonstration management.
 Project Implementation Plan - 51 - ANNEX A * nine months of local consultant time in media production, support to farmers marketing associations, guest speakers at local training sessions, and computing skills. D. Environmental Guidelines 42. In order to ensure sustainability of agriculture production and the safe use and handling of agrochemicals, MAF would develop environmental ("best practice") guidelines for the extension services in line with applicable environmental legislation no later than 12 months after effectiveness (see para. 7.2 in the SAR). E. Organization, Management and Implementation 43. The extension program would be managed and implemented through the Extension Division of the MAF headed by the Deputy Minister (Extension). There will be three tiers of management (i) MAF Headquarters (ii) Zupanija Extension Service Centers (iii) Farmer advisers 44. The extension program would be managed and implemented through the Extension Division established within MAF under the Deputy Minister (Extension). The extension service is a separate operations service, has its own budget and permanent staff. The extension division would be responsible for its own staff recruitment. A recent staff ranking system has been established which provides for all professional staff to improve their position based on merit. 45. The HQ staff comprise an operations manager, information/media officer, a general agriculturalist with comprehensive experience in dealing with farmers, and a training officer. HEADQUARTERS STAFFNG 46. The HQ Division, apart from the general management of the service, would have the following broad functions: (i) Designing and coordinating the training programs: reorientation, in-service and technical; (ii) selecting candidates for overseas training; (iii) collaboration with the Agriculture Research Council in defining national research priorities; (iv) reviewing existing research requests and identifying technology gaps between "progressive" and "average" farmers in the formulation of short-term extension advice - packages; (v) maintain linkages to the research community
 ANNEX A - 52 - Project Implementation Plan (vi) providing technical, economic and market information to field extension staff, and generally sustaining a farmer profit-oriented approach to be promoted by extension staff; and (vii) participation in and developing mass media programs. TRANING 47. Training of trainers. All field staff recruited to the new extension service would require extensive re-training. In view of the comprehensive training programs required, it is proposed to first implement a trainers' program to produce qualified staff to cater for the various training needs prior to project start- up of field operations. The training of 12 trainers (eight general agriculturalists and four with farm management/economics experience) and who are receptive to new ideas would be supported. It is expected that these trainers would also evolve into leadership functions within the extension service. This trainers' program would be funded under a Japanese Grant Fund. 48. The trainers would complete an intensive two-month course which would include the following general subjects: a market economy and how it operates; the meaning of economic competitiveness from the production perspective - focusing on profit increases, rather than production; the changing economy and its implications for farmers for their production mix, and for extension; the role and potential of small family farms, advantages and disadvantages; investment analysis; gross margin and whole farm system analysis; participatory constraint analysis of the family farm; how to learn from farmers - listening as an effective tool in gaining farmers' confidence; public speaking skills, the use of extension aids to teaching and learning; extension through farmer groups - group dynamics and management, how to formn extension groups; the need for and advantages of continuing interaction between extension agents researchers and farmers. To the extent necessary, familiarization with computers and the necessary analytical tools would be included in the training program. The training would be practically orientated, with regular on-farm exercises interacting with farm families operating differing production systems with various resource capacities. The training specialist would prepare guidelines and course material for extension staff training to be carried out by the trainers. 49. Reorientation training. The reorientation training would cover all extension staff. Over the first two years of the project, the total staff complement would receive training. The course would focus on the operational changes needed to effectively transfer relevant information which would be adopted by farmers. A two-week course would be held based on the curricula outlined above. Each training course for about ten officers would be carried out by the trainers over a two-week period. Provision is made for other specialists, including the media to participate. The program would be organized by the training specialist of MAF's Extension Department. 50. In-service technical training. In-service training would focus on up-to-date technology development from research, the latest development in market opportunities and on the extension themes developed for various farming systems. This training schedule would provide for a forum to discuss current farm constraints encountered by field staff. Regular in-service training would be central to maintaining a responsive and motivated extension operation and establish a base for research extension dialogue. The training officer from HQ would prepare and organize the program. The four Zonal Research Extension Coordination Units (ZERCU) to be supported under the project would play a vital role, both in delivery of technical packages and as listeners to problems identified by extension staff. The media would also be involved and would benefit from the subject matter discussions for the formulation
 Project Implementation Plan - 53 - ANNEX A of their programs. The training sessions would be for one week and would be supported by other specialists as found relevant. Inputs would be required from agribusiness, banks and progressive farmers. 51. Overseas training. Eight officers (four agro-economists and four extension officers) would be selected for overseas visits of three months during the first three years of the project. The visits program would be set up to cater both for short formal courses in extension methodology and practical exposure to operations in the field. The candidates would have shown the necessary aptitude to absorb and communicate and would necessarily have fluency in a West European language. On return, the trainees would be required to hold a series of seminars for extension staff and be required to participate in in- service staff training courses. MONIORING AND CONTROL OF THE EXTENSION SERVICE 52. Baseline survey. Monitoring and control functions are essential for effective management. The effectiveness of extension programs are very difficult to assess because of the wide range of factors that affect farmer decision making and profitability most of which are outside the control of the extension staff. (Price movements and weather patterns are obvious examples). Nevertheless the changes in the farming community need to be identified. To identify whether progress towards the objectives has been made, a baseline survey would be carried out by the Institute of Agriculture Economic in Year one of the project and that it is repeated in five years time to assess changes. The survey would aim to measure current production parameters and farmer attitudes. (See Chapter VIII, on Policy Analysis Unit.) 53. Component Performance. In addition, MAF's Department of Extension and Agriculture would be responsible for monitoring project performance on the basis of the indicators outlined in Annex D.) SHE ZUPANIA EXTENSION SERVICE CENTERS (ZESCS) 54. The 21 centers would be strengthened during the first two years of the project. Although based at the Zupanija administrative centers, the ZESC staff would report directly on technical and operational matters to their headquarters in Zagreb. The administrative head of the Zupanija would be fully informed of the content and planning of field extension programs and his advice and assistance sought in mobilization of the farmer community and to provide support and endorse media campaigns. The ZESCs would have no administrative responsibilities within the Zupanija structure. 55. ZESCAdvisory Committees would be established in each zupanija to assist the ZESC staff identify and meet the needs of the farmers. Membership would comprise of a majority of farmers with representatives of produce buyers and the supply industry. Initially members would be appointed by appropriate organizations including the Croatian Farmers Association. In future elections could be held. Total membership would be 9. The secretariat would be provided by the ZESC. Committee Members would represent the Zupanija on the advisory board of the Zonal Research Extension Coordination Units (see Chapter IV, on Research). 56. The ZESC team would maintain a close liaison and give operational support to the Advisory Committees who would be their link to the formulation of research programs. They would provide information on technical and market constraints. 57. Each Zupanija has a different density of farmers and mix of farm holding sizes and systems. Given the limited number of staff available and the large number of farmers the Zupanija extension service would be structured as a resource center with four main objectives:
 ANNEX A - 54 - Project Implementation Plan (i) To provide information to private sector and other 'front line' advisers. (ii) To encourage the establishment of self help farmer groups. (iii) To provide specialist support and advice to advisers and farmers. (iv) To provide feedback to MAF headquarters. 58. The center would be staffed by a senior extension specialist (The Center Manager), supported by 3-4 specialists, depending on the agricultural importance of the area, its cropping systems and the mix of enterprises. Additional extension staff may be provided by the Zupanija (As is the case at Poric.) 59. Some individual farmer advice is inevitable and will continue to be necessary. Farmers will continue to visit the extension officer and field visits by staff will be required to ensure that problems have been correctly diagnosed and to establish the context in which the request for advice has been made. Other visits will be necessary in order that the ZESC staff keep in touch with the needs of the farming industry. This could occupy about 15 per cent of an adviser's time. 60. The ZESCs would operate through farmer groups and rely heavily on videos and listening tapes and the use of mass media (radio, television and the press). Farmers groups would be set up and group responsibilities allocated to individual officers and routine visit programs organized. To provide adequate coverage of groups (20 groups with about 20 farmers) and assuming 4-5 visits/year, the extension officer would be required to spend about three days/week in the field. These visits would be supported by field demonstrations prepared by the farmers themselves with guidance from the extension officer. These demonstrations would support the thematic approach which is the core of the methodology and would concentrate on lower production costs, improved profitability, market demand, comparative advantage, chemical application rates, increasing farmer bargaining power, improvements in tillage, and soil moisture management, irrigation investment, analysis, etc. MAss MEDIA EXTENSION 61. The mass media already make a substantial contribution to the dissemination of farmer information. Farm programs have a wide audience, and considerable scope exists for expansion of the service. The project would therefore seek to generate a substantial information base for program content. The training officer in the Ministry would be responsible for the co-ordination of mass media extension and for developing information channels. He would have funds at his disposal to employ local media consultants for specific tasks. ROLE OF THE PRIVATE SECTOR 62. The principle of a limited public extension system operating at Zupanija level is fully supported by MAF. MAF also wishes to control recurrent costs and to retain highly qualified staff and to invest in their training and equipment. It is fully realized that initially they will be resource persons, and individual farmer contact will be limited; considerable emphasis is therefore laid on the use of multiple communication channels, including mass media. 63. MAF supports the provision of 'front line' advice by private extension and consultancy services. There is a pool of staff available from the former municipalities and from the AK support services that could be gainfully employed in a private sector role, complementary to the public services proposed. 64. The project would encourage the use of paid-for services, which meet a demand, from farmers organizations/associations (individual well-off farmers have generally access to good information).
 Project Implementation Plan - 55 - ANNEX A 65. There are no legal obstacles to the formation of private consulting companies. F. Envrionmental Impact 66. The modification to tillage practices would have a positive effect on improving infiltration rates and soil moisture relationships. There will be a positive effect on controlling run-off and soil and wind erosion. 67. The overall strengthening of the extension service would assist farmers in the safe and rational use of plant protection chemicals. The increased use of integrated pest management techniques, awarded priority under the adaptive research program, should provide for a general reduction in chemical use.  Project Implementation Plan - 59 - ANNEX A IV. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR AGRICULTURE RESEARCH A. Components Objectives and Activities SUMMARY 68. The main objective of the component would be to develop a research service responsive to serving the requirements of private farm families now operating in a market economy. More specific objectives would be: (i) to initiate and sustain a process where past academic and production orientated research is replaced by a more analytical, multidisciplinary, economic and producer constraint orientated approach; (ii) to establish effective participation of producers in identifying priorities for research and deciding on allocation of funds to research projects; (iii) to introduce rational planning of research projects to resolve readily identifiable constraints at farm level, with due consideration of the total socio-economic farm system; (iv) to provide for a system which can generate research projects, award priorities and effectively implement them; (v) to develop strong linkages between research and extension through which technology transfer and information flow maintains relevance to farmers' needs; (vi) to better equip the research services to adjust to the requirements of private farming needs and to enable them to implement contract research at field level; 69. Component Activities would consist of the following: 70. The Agriculture Research Council. The project would support an applied agriculture research management system to produce relevant and timely information for the private family farmers. The establishment of an independent Agriculture Research Council (ARC) which would establish research policy and priorities for funding applied agriculture research would be key to ensuring relevance and timeliness of research to farmers. The ARC would consist of a majority of farmer representatives (9 members nominated from each of the nine agriculture regions). The chairperson would be appointed by the Minister of Agriculture and Forestry upon nomination of the ARC. Other council members would consist of a representative of MAF, a representative from the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), three representatives of the scientific community, and one from the agrobusiness sector. The research agenda would be (i) open-ended and determined by the ARC, and (ii) would allow for a broad scope of topics to be researched ranging from production technology to market research and development. Any bona fide Croatian research institution, public or private, would be eligible to participate under the competitive research grant system. 71. Demand-driven research. The ARC would invite the scientific community (both public and private sector) on the basis of publicly announced Terms of Reference, to submit research proposals to the council, i.e. contracts for applied research would be demand driven. The ARC shall make such
 ANNEX A - 60 - Project Implementation Plan rules and establish procedures as required openly to carry out its responsibility. The Council shall also promulgate procedures and select participants for external and internal training of scientific and faculty personnel supported under the project. MOST would carry out the technical and scientific review (involving national and foreign reviewers) of the submitted proposals and would submit to the ARC shortlists of proposals in the respective areas of applied research for decision making. MOST would administer, supervise (including on-site supervision) and audit the research contracts. The ARC would be assisted by a small (one or two) person secretariat which would call the ARC meetings on the initiative of the Chairperson. It would also be responsible to liaise with MOST and to also carry-out on-site supervision of applied research contracts. 72. Agriculture Research Fund. Applied agriculture research would be funded on a competitive grant basis through an Agriculture Research Fund which would finance incremental equipment and research costs. In the context of applied research, MOST would continue, as in the past, to finance the salaries and basic operating costs of the public research institutions; MOST would also continue to support basic agriculture research (including salaries, buildings, utilities and equipment) and continue to support and pay for post graduate students. 73. The Agriculture Research Fund would be established under the authority of the ARC. During project implementation this fund would be financed to a large extent through the World Bank loan (roughly estimated at around 80%) with the balance from budget allocations (roughly 20%). In order to ensure that both regional and national research priorities are being addressed a funding formula would be agreed upon by the ARC, for a period not shorter than three years, which would allocated funds to the main agriculture regions (based on the relative contribution to agriculture GDP) and to overall national research. In order to ensure financial sustainability of the Agriculture Research Fund, MAF is committed to introduce in the course of project implementation modest commodity based levies paid by the producer, once the overall concept has gained credibility within the farming community. This credibility is largely a function of the relevance and quality of the applied research and the associated independence of the ARC. 74. Research - Extension - Farmer Linkages would be strengthened through the following steps: (i) relevance of future applied research would be improved by the above approach, which focuses on farmer representation both at the district and the national level. At the district level, extension and research would be guided by farmer advisory committees, the ZESC Advisory Committees, and Zonal Advisory Committees of four small Zonal Research Extension Coordination Units. These district and zonal advisory committees would meet regularly, and would guide the initiatives of the Zupanija extension staff. The Zonal Research Extension Coordination Units, each consisting of two professional staff, would establish a formal link between the research community (in particular with researcher under contract from the ARC), and the public and private extension services, and would assist in the coordination of on-field trials and demonstrations. A first Zonal Research Extension Coordination Unit would be established in the second year of the project, while the other three be set up subsequently after evaluation of the performance of the first unit. At the national level, farmer representatives, nominated by their peers from the district and zonal Advisory Committee, would ensure that farmers' problems become the focus of the future research agenda; (ii) invitations for applied research proposals would request a concept by the bidder on how the research results would reach the extension services and farmers; this concept would be part of the overall proposal evaluation;
 Project Implementation Plan - 61 - ANNEX A (iii) the project has budgeted for field trials and demonstrations to be carried out by the extension services; the field trials would be linked to the research proposals in order to ensure on-farm experimentation. The successful research bidder would engage in contracts with individual farmers to carry out on-farm trials under the supervision of the researcher. 75. Project support. The project would support the establishment of the ARC by providing: (i) technical assistance (partly through a Japanese Grant) to initially work out and during implementation improve the operational procedures of the competitive grant based research management system; (ii) office and computer equipment, and a vehicles; and (iii) covering initial operating costs of the Council and the secretariat. 76. The project would provide the ARC with an Agriculture Research Fund of roughly US$5.2 million over four years which would finance all the public supported applied and adoptive agricultural research (including equipment requirements) carried out in the country during the course of project implementation. The amount to be provided under the Agriculture Research Fund has been established in function of the amount of resources that could be levied from the farming community in the future; and by estimating costs of four indicative research programs identified by the research community as being of potentially high priority. Basic agricultural research would remain under the auspices of MOST. 77. ORGANIZATION, MANAGEMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION DESIGN OF REQUESTS FOR PROPOSALS 102. The following provides guidelines for the development of the operational procedures for the ARC which wuld take place in late 1995 with Technical Assistance financed under a Japanese Grant in collaboration between MAF and MOST. 103. The universal experience is that scientists like to do research and take every opportunity to secure funding for their research programs. Another observation is that scientists are willing to change their research activities to accommodate the requirements of the funding sources or the sponsors. It also was apparent that many faculty, research institutes and former "agro-kombinat" research specialists are interested in doing applied research of immediate relevance to farmers. While no laboratory is ever "fully equipped", and with the possible exception of the dislocated faculty at Osijek, agricultural scientists in Croatia seem to feel their facilities are mostly adequate to undertake the private farmer focused research needed. No doubt that greater international contacts in the future will reveal deficiencies that the Agricultural Research Council should work to rectify. 104. The large number of potential investigators who have had very little if no research funding from the state in the recent past and the large range of topics this group of scientists could address, makes it imperative that the topics for research be carefully identified and described. This will permit those persons with skills to do the research required by the Agricultural Research Council to be able to identify their interest with the need and submit proposals. On the other hand it would not give false encouragement to those excellent scientists who do not have the right training and interest to perform the research needed. In short, a clearly stated request for research and extension proposals would avoid a flood of proposals that are not relevant and would help assure that the submitted proposals are most likely to meet the Council's requirements even though not all of them could be funded. Experience elsewhere has shown that there will be requests for more funds than are available. 105. Advisory Input: The structure of advisory councils at the Zupanija and zonal levels is focused to provide the majority of members on the Agriculture Research Council, assure that they are identified by the best available elective process and also assure they are private farmers. These advisory councils, especially at the zonal levels, have a stated responsibility to propose the extension and research needs to the Council. These facts and the desire to make the research relevant to farmer needs makes it of utmost importance that the advisory system is used and listened to during the planning of research thrusts to be supported each year. 106. Once started, advisory input to the Council should be continuous and suggestions accepted and kept on file until decisions are to be made on which will be pursued. Six weeks or two months before
 Project Implementation Plan - 67 - ANNEX A decisions are to be made on research thrusts once or twice a year, a reminder should go to all Zupanija and zonal offices that any additional suggestions should be submitted in order to be considered. Members of the Council from the various zones should also talk about extension and research needs whenever they meet with the Zonal Units and other farmers and they should bring suggestions they hear to Council meetings. 107. Administrative Determination: The Council will finally decide upon the fields in which it wishes to request proposals for projects. Having done so, it should scrupulously follow its own requests relative to proposals to consider. Even if a very good proposal that does not fit the criteria announced is received it should be deferred. If a non-conforming proposal is a worthwhile idea, the Council may add it to the next round of requests for proposals and perhaps receive even better proposals from among which to choose. 108. It is suggested that research awards be made twice a year because both fall sown and spring sown crops are common and they represent entirely different species in most cases. The call for proposals would make this clear in the announcement. In addition to permitting scientists better to utilize recently collected data, the two awarding dates would spread the work load for the Council as well as its secretariat. Making more frequent awards of funds might overwhelm a system that is just beginning to function. 109. Eligibility for Funding: Any bona fide Croatian research institute, public or private, would be eligible to participate in this competitive grant research approach. REsARCH AND/OR EXTENSION PROPOSALS 110. In order to fulfill the close association of research with extension and to assure that research will be relevant to private farms, all applied field work needs to be evaluated by a standardized procedure even if different priorities are given to adaptive, applied and strategic research and demonstrations. 111. Some funding agencies which expect large volumes of projects use a two-step process. The first step is a preproposal and, as implied, is a short description of the project. Usually a length limit, e.g., 2 pages or 3 pages of text is set plus, the budget sheet. These are quickly evaluated and those that interest the sponsor would be developed into a full proposal in the form of the project outline discussed above. Those of no further interest would be dropped from consideration. 112. Evaluation: This procedure is done on both the preproposal and/or the full proposal. It would be done for the Council by a panel of anonymous reviewers who do not have a direct relationship to the project under the guidance of MOST. 113. If these were preproposals, the Council would look carefully at the documents and evaluation and identify those of greatest interest. It would then determine the cost of these based upon the budgets and determine how many could be funded at the full levels, and if all proposals would still be as interesting or if the order could be changed or budgets adjusted. Then a decision would be made on which scientists would be asked to submit a full proposal. 114. Funding: The final step is for the Council to decide which projects to fund, for how long and at what level of funding, perhaps negotiating for lower expenses by reducing the project or other means.
 ANNEX A - 68 - Project Implementation Plan 115. Fairness and good morale both demand that reasonable research expenditures be made in all regions. There are several ways to do this, but one way of allocating funds regionally can be described in the request for proposals is based on a certain part of the total funds available divided equally among the zones and the rest on the basis of a formula. For example, 25% could be allocated for good proposals equally among the zones, and the balance allocated on the basis of number of private farms, the rural population, gross agricultural product, hectares of arable land, etc., or a combination of two or, no more than, three. So, as an example again, the remaining 75% of the funds could be allocated equally based on number of private farms and hectares of cultivated crops. There should always be a provision that if enough acceptable good proposals did not come from some zone, the unused funds would be allocated among the others by the formula. The cost of the secretariat and the cost of Agricultural Research Council activities would be taken out before allocation. New equipment or machinery needs would be a part of the project proposals. New permanent facilities would be handled outside the ARC funding process. REPORTING AND DEFENSE 116. A formal written report of progress must be required at least once a year for all funded projects. This written report would be due a month or six weeks before new projects are considered for funding and previously funded projects scheduled for extension for the second or subsequent years of their planned terms. Oral reports would also be given at the time just prior to when new awards are to be made. These two reports would give the Agricultural Research Council an opportunity to decide whether the project has made progress enough to justify its continuation or whether it should be terminated because it is not ever likely to succeed. 117. If the Council decides to proceed with projects starting twice a year, then the report reading and hearing tasks would be spread and the job of overseeing the results made easier. In case projects are funded only once a year, the reporting could be made a month earlier so tentative decisions on continuing projects could be out of the way before new projects are considered. If an outstanding new project surfaces, the Council could still give it preference over a previously funded project that may be making less than normal progress. 118. In addition to Council members at the oral report meetings, the science professionals from the Zonal Units should be present for the reports along with all the principal investigators making reports as well as members of the technical review panels. It is important for the Zonal Unit coordinators to be present so all can hear what has been achieved in the other three zones. The technical review panel members will benefit because these reports will help them better to understand research problems and perhaps make better evaluations for future proposals. They could also be used to help evaluate the progress reported, in which case the would meet privately with the Council after the oral presentations. These procedures are regularly used in progress evaluation. Again, the Council will have to conclude its own evaluation because it is the final authority responsible for the research done with the funds expended. 119. One purpose of oral presentations is to allow questions to be asked from the audience so that the investigators can defend their procedures, data collection, analysis of data and conclusions drawn. This exercise will also be informative to Council members who will have to make more decisions about these and other projects. It will enable them and the technical review panel members also to give advice or suggestions on how to make the studies more meaningful and may also help them write better requests for proposals.

Research results of applied studies will have no practical value until they are taken to farmers, explained and farmers begin to adopt them. The information will need to be expressed in lay language for farmers to study and understand. There are a number of ways in which information can be disseminated. Some are listed as follows: (i) Reports by the Agricultural Research Council of projects that are funded and where they will be conducted. (ii) Opportunities for farmers to view demonstrations and experiments during their development. (iii) Local reports on radio, television, and newspaper reporting what is happening. (iv) Reports of the results at the end of the season at the time the written report is due. (v) News of demonstrations planned on the basis of what more complex experiments have shown. (vi) Writing of pamphlets or bulletins for farmer use with the Zonal Unit science professionals and research investigators cooperating. (vii) Hold instructional meetings for farmers in each Zupanija. (viii) Hold informational meetings for extension professionals and farm advisors in each zone. 121. As always, scientists should be encouraged also to publish their work in scientific and technical journals and bulletins. These publications would be a legitimate cost of doing research. While these scientific papers might be slower in becoming published, the publications for extension use need to be distributed as soon as possible by oral, visual or written means. The urgency of changing the nature of agriculture in Croatia demands that information be released promptly and put into use as soon as it is prudently possible. MONITORING 122.  ANNEX A - 70 - Project Implementation Plan V. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR ANIMAL HEALTH SUPPORT SERVICES A. DETAILED DESIGN FEATURES 123. Current constraints with livestock disease control in Croatia, and to a lesser degree veterinary epidemiology, are associated with outdated diagnostic equipment, inadequately trained staff, insufficient resources for monitoring aspects of animal health and food quality particularly food residues, and inefficient data management and information dissemination. Project investment would assist in providing the basic resources to overcome these constraints and is focused on the government veterinary sector were these services are expected to remain for the foreseeable future, due to the public goods nature of these services. 124. Summary. Animal Health would be improved through the strengthening of epidemiological services leading to better disease identification and eradication programs. The National Veterinary Institute (NVI) and its four regional branches would be provided with vehicles and a comprehensive range of equipment to intensify the national disease surveillance program, a process which would be complemented by strengthened border quarantine posts. NVI national and regional animal health data bases would be linked to a strengthened MAF epidemiological service, and MAF's national disease reporting service strengthened to support national disease eradication and international disease reporting requirements. Private and public veterinarian technical and managerial skills would be improved through local and overseas training. The National Veterinary Chamber would be strengthened. International specialists would support the data management and veterinarian training programs. 125. Detailed Features. Veterinary epidemiological services of the NVI would be reinforced by provision of two national epidemiologist and two vehicles for field work, the development of a epidemiological information service, establishment of a comprehensive Enzyme Linked Immuno-sorbent Assay (ELISA)-based diagnostic service2 and through additional equipment to selected departments of NVI, particularly the food residue detection laboratory (Table 1). Equipment would also be provided for mastitis monitoring and blood, faecal and plant tissue analysis capability in support private veterinary practices and farmers participating in a whole herd health program. 126. The four regional diagnostic centers would be assisted with ELISA and other equipment to enable them to support the national epidemiological service and regional whole herd health programs (Table 2). Equipment would also be provided to the Poultry Institute in Zagreb to strengthen its support capacity (Table 2). Overseas training programs, estimated at 18 person months, for staff at the NVI and regional laboratories would address deficiencies in disease diagnostic capability and be linked to the supply of new equipment and services. 2/ ELISA is an immunoassay test which is superseding more traditional disease identification tests, particularly for infectious diseases. Its advantages include low cost, high speed, field applicability and relatively high enzyme-labeled antibodies or anti-immunoglobulins, which attach themselves respectively to the infective viral/bacterial antigens or antibodies (produced in response to disease infection) in the sample. Color-coded "detectors" are subsequnetly added to provide visual evidence of infection.

Disease reporting and information management would be improved with the establishment of a computer network linking MAF's Zupanije (i.e., district level) veterinary inspection services and MAF's border control posts to NVI (Table 3). This would be first initiated in project Year 1, and expanded to the full network in Year 2 after proving effectiveness. A standard word processing and database management software package would also be provided with each unit. Technical assistance support of 5 person-months to design and test an integrated data base and familiarize staff with its use would also be provided. Additional technical assistance would include two person-months for whole herd health management and three person-months for veterinary epidemiology (2 visits). 128. Six all terrain vehicles, one each to the NVI, the four regional institutes and the Poultry Institute, would be provided for field investigation and sample transfer work. Each vehicle would be fitted with a post-mortem kit, field microscope and transportable cold chain. Two liaison vehicles would also be provided to NVI (Table 4). 129. Each of the border control posts where veterinary inspection staff are based, would be supplied with a computer system including a laser printer and modem for connection to a national network for the transfer of disease reports and related epidemiological information. The project would provide 20 person months (two weeks per staff member) of introductory training for Zupanije veterinary inspectors in computer operation and the use of the custom-designed data management software package (see para 10). 130. A project financed re-orientation training program (Table 5) would be designed to provide private veterinary practices with the technical and management skills needed for efficient operation. In parallel with the Zupanije program, one veterinary doctor per practice would be provided an introductory course in computers and related office and data management (50 person-months). The project would contract the Croatian Veterinary Faculty (working in collaboration with the Veterinary Chamber) to identify and design a series of short courses for private veterinary practitioners on technical subjects including, though not limited to, whole herd health and production management, fertility management, ruminant and non- ruminant nutrition, artificial insemination, management-related disease, animal housing and welfare, small animal work and ELISA technology. Course work would be structured to fit the work program of a private veterinary practice by regional weekend or evening seminars and tutorials. Provision has been made for the preparation on contract of 10 such courses, including all course teaching materials, at an estimated cost of US$ 10,000 each. Participants would pay in advance a course fee to cover the recurrent costs of the course including lecturers' salaries. 131. The support provided to NVI and the regional institutes would not entail any additional staffing. An estimate of additional recurrent costs to make full use of the equipment that would be supplied by the project is US$ 250,000 per annum or 10 per cent of the investment cost. It is expected that these cost will be largely recovered through inspection fees. 132. This component would also provide short term support to Croatian animal health services by assisting the fledgling Veterinary Chamber to provide technical, ethical and professional support to veterinary doctors in Croatia, subject to the legal recognition of the Veterinary Chamber under the new Veterinary Law. It is expected that a successful and efficient support organization for the veterinary profession would attract the majority of qualified veterinary doctors who are presently not members and would thus become even more effective in its support and regulatory functions. 133. Support would include equipping the Chamber's office (furniture, photocopier, communications equipment and computer hardware and software); the publication of a Croatian Veterinary Code; and the cost of publishing 12 issues of a quarterly veterinary newsletter (Table 6).

BENEFTs AND BENEFIcIARES 135. The expected benefits from this program are: (i) an increased capacity of the regulatory veterinary services to diagnose and control the major diseases of animal and public health importance; (ii) a national, readily accessible data bank on disease distribution and occurrence to assist Government in policy and planning work and to fulfil its obligations toward disease reporting to the international community; (iii) capability by the statutory veterinary institutes to analyze products of animal origin intended for human consumption and use thus ensuring protection of public safety and health; (iv) the capacity to monitor quality of exported food products thereby protecting the integrity of existing markets and opening opportunity for new markets, particularly for "healthy" foods; (v) an improved diagnostic and clinical service for farmers through the regulatory and private veterinary services; (vi) an effective professional and regulatory body for animal health matters; and (vii) a body of veterinary doctors aware of and competent to carry out the professional services required of them by the farming community. 136.  Project Implementation Plan - 83 - ANNEX A VI. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR PASTURE AND FODDER DEVELOPMENT A. OBJECTIVE 141. The objective of the pasture program would be to reduce the cost of livestock production to private farmers, to reduce reliance on expensive concentrate feeds and hence increase the competitiveness of the livestock subsector by developing grassland production both on natural and sown pastures. Upland areas would be made more productive through increased yields of natural grasslands and better management. There would also be closer integration of livestock and crops in the agricultural systems of the lowlands, leading to increased farm productivity. B. DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS 142. Pasture is among the most under-utilized resources in Croatia. Improved pasture and fodder productivity, in terms of quality, quantity and seasonality of supply, could help reduce ruminant livestock production costs and enable diversification of production. The enhancement of the upland grazing industry could see the emergence of a pasture based upland cattle and sheep industry supplying weaned, immature stock to lowland fatteners. Grassland-based livestock farmiing also offers the opportunity for the entry into the industry of a much needed younger generation of farmers. Research into both sustainable technology for incremental pasture production and the farming systems and sociological settings where the technology is to be applied should help support the maintenance of the relatively undisturbed environment that still pertains over much of Croatia. This would auger well for future niche marketing of eco-friendly agricultural products amongst others, strengthened by project-based government incentives in support of private market development initiatives. 143. Pasture research in Croatia in the past has been directed to the development of sustainable, livestock grazing-based production systems. Most pasture development has, however, focused on uneconomic changes to the environment as the means of increasing perennial pasture productivity. Expensive drainage and uneconomic liming and fertilization practices have made pasture improvement uneconomic for private farmers. These policies have led to considerable government subsidy but only limited pasture development. 144. Government policy in the past has been unfavorable to the emergence of a pasture based livestock industry and subsidies favored grain-based livestock feeding systems. A core scientific group continued to investigate pasture production but its activities were severely curtailed by policy and funding restrictions. The result has been limited progress in the development and particularly demonstration of appropriate technology. However, with this small core scientific resource in place, opportunities for technology transfer from similar environments and production systems in neighboring countries and with its participation in a regional pasture research and development network, Croatia is well placed to organize the rapid development of its pasture resource. The project would address the most immediate of these constraints through investment in an applied, and more particularly adaptive, research program closely linked to the work of the extension service.
 ANNEX A - 84 - Project Implementation Plan 145. A re-oriented pasture development strategy would include: emphasis on species having low fertilizer requirements and better adaptation to local agro-climatic conditions; modification only of the micro-environment around the young plant; increased attention to marginal returns to incremental fertilization; and management of the improved sward. Exhaustive testing of alternative species, particularly legumes, lime coating of inoculated seed, establishment of yield response curves to macro- and micro-element (particularly molybdenum and sulphur on acid soils) and animal manure application, increased supplies of single element fertilizer (particularly superphosphate), and improving and maintaining pasture quality are key actions required to support a more cost-effective pasture development strategy. With regard to pasture resource management, the establishment of land lease legislation, the setting and policing of stock carrying capacity, and investment in low cost (electric) fencing would be pre- requisites to effective management. 146. The process of forage development must be supported by research. Some possible strategies require further research before being available for commercial application but many are inmediately implementable and could become the focus of a restructured extension service. The introduction of wrapped silage as a means of fodder conservation by contractor service is also a promising avenue. Plastic wrapped round-bale silage optimizes ensiling conditions and minimizes wastage were only small daily quantities are needed. Another significant advantage offered by silage production is the capacity to maintain production almost irrespective of weather conditions, thus allowing timely harvest particularly with respect to fodder quality (digestibility and protein content). 147. On-farm Technology Testing (OFTT) and field demonstration and the monitoring of management systems adopted by leading farmers would be required to support the research program. Minimum tillage is likely to play a big role in forage development through cost reductions and opportunities for relay cropping resulting from more timely field operations. Unravelling the complexities of the practical application of reduced-tillage farming systems would require tenacious research effort, and, as with the pasture research program, much of it must be conducted on private farm holdings under practical management conditions. C. DETAILED DESIGN FEATURES 148. The development of a grass-fed livestock industry would be supported through the implementation of an applied and adaptive pasture development and research program, On-Farm Technology Testing (OFTT), and demonstrations. The existing upland pasture research station at Sljeme 35 km from Zagreb on Zagreb Mountain would be strengthened and research capability for lowland pasture and fodder crops would be enhanced. Scientific staff skills would be strengthened, primarily through post-graduate training, regional study tours and improved linkage with the FAO European Research Cooperative Network on Pastures and Fodder Crops. Extension staff experience would be developed through participation in the implementation of the OFTT and demonstration program, backed by in-service training. 149. The pasture development program would commence with a detailed assessment of the national pasture resource by agro-ecological zone. The study would detail ownership, distribution and use patterns of pastures, species mix and productivity, and agro-climatic and soil conditions. It would include the preparation of a bibliography of published and unpublished scientific literature on pasture and fodder production in Croatia. This part of the program would be implemented under contract by the Department of Forage and Grassland Production of the Zagreb Faculty of Agriculture. When completed, the report would form the basis for the development of a national strategy for the integration of pastures and forages
 Project Implementation Plan - 85 - ANNEX A into livestock farming systems. Two person-weeks of technical assistance would be provided to support this work. In addition, the expertise of a livestock/pasture economist would be provided to give the future pasture and fodder development program a stronger economic focus. 150. The project would support an applied and adaptive pasture and fodder research program, initially in conditions relative to the mountain/upland agro-ecological zones. The research program would include an OFTT program (where much of the field equipment listed in Table 1 would be deployed), implemented in collaboration with the extension service and other regional research stations. The research program would commence in Year 1 in the upland and continental areas, and Year 2 in the mediterranean area at the Agricultural Research Institute at Split. The Institute would implement the adaptive research program under the supervision of the Department of Forage and Grassland Production. 151. The Zagreb University upland pasture research farm at Sljeme would be upgraded for use as a training center in pasture management and livestock production. With only six scientists currently actively working on pasture and fodder production, there is an urgent need to develop a cadre of younger scientists to lead future research and development of this grossly under-utilized resource. The project would finance three postgraduate programs in subjects including but not limited to species adaptation, fertilizer response, fodder crop production, pasture/soil management, livestock production from pasture, and pasture pests and disease. Students would receive external postgraduate training but would do associated research work in Croatia. Supervisors of students would visit Croatia to support field research work on a technical assistance (per diem and travel only) basis for a total of eight person-weeks. Zupanije extension staff would receive training in pasture and fodder management and subsequently participate in regular in-service training programs in pasture management. Pasture management extension programs would be developed and promoted through Zupanija Extension Service Centers. Funds for on- farm pasture management demonstrations would also be provided under the project. 152. Finance would also be provided to strengthen the fodder corn and pasture legume breeding and species adaptation work being conducted by the Agricultural Faculty of Zagreb University. Specifically the project would finance a limited scope of field equipment to support an expanded variety trials program, plot-scale seed processing equipment, one field vehicle, a desktop computer and the cost of incremental laboratory services. 153. The program would be closely linked to the work of the FAO European Research Cooperative Network on Pastures and Fodder Crops (ERCNPFC). The project would provide funds for the active participation of Croatian pasture and fodder scientists in ERCNPFC collaborative research programs and associated international meetings. 154. The support provided by the project to the University of Zagreb would not entail any additional staffing. Additional recurrent costs to make full use of the equipment that would be supplied by the project is estimated at US$24,000 per year for the laboratory equipment and US$12,000 for field work elements or a total of US$36,000 per year. D. PASTURE AND FORAGE PROGRAM COSTS 155. The total cost (including contingencies) of the Pasture and Forage Development Prograin amounts to US$2.3 million. A detailed cost breakdown is given in Annex D, Table 2.4.
 ANNEX A - 86 - Project Implementation Plan E. BENEFITS AND BENEFICIARIES 156. The expected benefits from pasture and fodder development include: (i) increased productivity and cost effectiveness of extensive sheep farming from low-cost upland pasture improvement, (ii) increased (possibly doubled) dry matter production of upland pastures to yield energy for ruminants at about 20 per cent of the cost of concentrates and a potential to produce an additional 0.4 million tonnes of milk or 0.1 million tonnes of beef; (iii) high productivity at significantly reduced cost from conservation of high quality roughage resulting in potential milk yields of 4,000-4,500 litres per lactation and live weight gains of 1 kg per day on rations based on 60 per cent maize silage and 40 per cent leguminous forage; and, (iv) strengthened livestock-crop integration. 157. The beneficiaries would be the farmers in both upland permanent grasslands and in lowland mixed farms. It is expected that the low cost systems proposed would also favor young people entering into agricultural production. F. COMPONENT MANAGEMENT 158. The pasture and fodder development program and the postgraduate training program would be coordinated by the Department of Fodder and Grassland Production, Zagreb University, which would take full responsibility for management of the applied research program in coordination with three regional research institutions (Porice, Split and Osijek). The Department of Fodder and Grassland Production would also be responsible for developing the technical specifications of the field and laboratory equipment to be procured under the project (see Table 1). 159. The OFTT and field demonstration program would be coordinated nationally by the Department for Forage and Grassland Production. Zupanije Extension Service Centers would implement the demonstration program in collaboration with interested farmers and use the trials and demonstrations as a focal point for field days and farmer group visits. Technical advisors employed by livestock product processors and input suppliers would be encouraged to participate actively in this program. G. IMPLEMENTATION 160. The program would be implemented over four years. The grasslands inventory would be completed and the report written up and the bibliography produced by the end of the first year of the project. 161. The civil works related to the new infrastructure and repair of the existing facilities of the Sljeme Pasture Research Station would be initiated at the beginning of the first year of the project and be completed and operational by end-year two.
 Project Implementation Plan - 87 - ANNEX A 162. Training of extension workers would be spread evenly over the life of the project. The three postgraduate studies would be awarded in first two project years.  Project Implementation Plan - 89 - ANNEX A VII. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR SEED INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT A. OBJECTIVE 163. The objective of this component is to improve the regulatory and administrative framework of the Croatian seed and plant genetic subsector, with a view to improving domestic plant genetic resources and increasing the industry's export market access and competitiveness. B. STRATEGIES 164. To overcome identified constraints (see Annex L, Supplemental Volume) and to improve the efficiency and credibility of the regulatory system as a whole, the project would (i) establish a unified seed industry quality control authority, supported by an adequate analytical capability, regulatory framework and enforcement capability; (ii) update and expand plant variety testing and registration procedures; (iii) establish conditions enabling Croatian membership of international seed organizations and (iv) re-establish the national gene bank. C. DETAILED PROPOSALS NATIONAL SEED AUTHORITY 165. The project would establish the National Seed Authority (NSA) as an agency separate from but answerable to the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (see Figure 1). The purpose of the new Authority would be to implement all regulatory and testing functions in plant agriculture as required under Croatian law in an impartial manner and to report the results to the Minister of Agriculture. The Authority would be supervised by a Board consisting of about 9 people, from academia, industry, and the MAF. The Authority will combine, under a single management structure, the functions and staff and physical resources of the MAF plant testing and border quarantine services, the Authority of Plant Protection, the Viticulture Institute and parts of the MAF Forestry Department. The Authority is expected to employ about 130 people, half of whom would be employed in border quarantine programs. While significant staff savings are projected from the coalescence of these organizations, about 25 incremental staff will be required to manage the VCU3 and DUS4 varietal testing program which will be moved from a contracted to an Authority implemented program. The NSA would, in time, become entirely self sustaining through service fees, as promulgated in the new draft Seed Law legislation. The NSA would include, central laboratory, computing, statistical, research and financial and administrative services supporting three Divisions, split on functional lines and responsible respectively for (1) Varietal Trials (VCU and DUS Trials Services), (2) Plant Material Certification (Field Inspection, Quality Testing and Certification Services), and (3) Plant Health (Border Quarantine, Integrated Pest Management and Agro- chemical Registration Services). Detailed descriptions of the laboratory, office and field equipment required to establish the NSA are contained part F (Field Trial Budget) of this chapter. 3/ Official varietal performance testing (Value for Cultivation and Use). 4/ Official varietal identification testing (Distinctness, Uniformity, Stability).
