The laboratory staff and equipment of the Plant Protection Institute would be transferred to the NSA and supported with additional equipment and one bacteriologist. Equally, the NSA Statistical Services, Financial Services and Administrative Services Units would comprise staff transferred from the Plant Protection Institute. The Research Unit would employ a single Research Coordinator responsible for channeling spare scientific capacity within the NSA toward competitive research contracts with the new Agricultural Research Council. The National Variety Listing Committee would comprise appointed experts under (i) the Chair-personship of MAF's Deputy Minister for Agriculture Production; (ii) with the Director NSA a permanent Committee member; and (iii) the Director, MAF Agriculture Department, the Committee secretary. The Committee would meet on an "as needs" basis. 167. The Plant Testing Division, would evaluate varieties for inclusion in a restructured National List. This would ensure that the National List gives farmer's an impartial assessment of those varieties which are reasonable to grow. This is different and separate from extension trials and demonstration; the purpose of the former is to give an estimate of the interaction between varieties. A variety would have to be distinct, uniform, stable and have adequate performance before it can be placed on the national list. The Division would consist of two Services with testing commencing with the agricultural crops and introducing horticultural crops in year three or four. The responsibilities of the units would be: (i) Performance Testing Service (VCU, value for cultivation and use); Variety Performance Trials. The objective of this Service would be to establish repeatable high quality trials which adequately discriminate between varieties and are run by unbiased, well qualified NSA staff. These would be carried out from three centers, a main center (Zagreb), a sub-center (central east) and a Mediterranean sub-center in Istria, the latter to be established once the two continental climate centers are operational. Each center would manage a series of satellite stations. Each center would be staffed by a qualified trials manager, a pathologist, 2-3 technicians and a tractor driver. Total staff would not exceed 6 persons. Casual labor would be employed as required. Land would be rented from farmers on an annual basis and trials laid out on each location. The trials locations would be serviced from each center on a day to day basis. Species would be grouped wherever possible and the travel distance kept to a minimum. This may require some relocation of the currently used sites. Yield and agronomic data would be collected in an organized and timely manner, from replicated trials following internationally accepted designs, under the control of one person (the center manager). Field trial protocols (reflecting local growing practices) would be written by the trials working group for each species and the center manager would be responsible to ensure they are carried out. (ii) Variety Identification Service (distinctness uniformity and stability, DUS); Plant Variety Discrimination. This Service would carry out trials under UPOV5 guidelines in such a manner as to allow the discrimination between varieties for Plant Variety Rights purposes. This function would be new to the trials Authority. One field center would be required for this morphological work6, provided irrigation was available and that a sample was kept to allow replanting as required. One team of four people would be established at the location (Zagreb) to do this work. Introducing the full range of species into this overall testing regime would require attention to detail, careful timing and organization because: (i) the appropriate regulations would have to be in place; (ii) a period of change-over would be required where both VCU systems (old and new) are running in parallel; and (iii) the DUS system would be introduced for several species and there is little or no experience of such work in the country. 168. The introduction of Plant Variety Rights (PVR) would mean that a sample of the proposed seed crop would need to be verified as authentic. It is proposed that when a variety is registered for seed production that a sample (drawn by a licensed sampler) be sent to the Seed Testing Center. They would grow it in small plots for detailed maturity and off-type analysis (thus avoiding the detail of checking large fields) and control along with the DUS group the distinctness of the variety, initially by morphological means but eventually with electrophoresis. UPOV proposes to allow the introduction of electrophoresis as a diagnostic tool in 1995. It is proposed to introduce maize to the new system first, because it is the crop from which the greatest genetic/agricultural improvement could be expected. This would be followed by winter wheat the next year and the balance of the cereals and other miscellaneous crops the year after. However, the spring planting season for maize was missed. This phasing is important because it would be unlikely that the proposed change-over would occur without constraints. An element of security would be achieved by running the old and new systems in parallel for a year. The old system would then be progressively phased out as the new one is phased in. The overlapping year serves two purposes (i) it ensures data is recorded from both systems (ii) it ensures a lot of data is recorded, thus allowing a good estimate of variety value to be achieved to allow a significant rejection of poor varieties from the National List. 169. The reference collection, i.e. those varieties already on the national list, would need to be established before any additional varieties are added, because, it is against these that all new variety distinctness characteristics must be quantified for DUS purposes. The reason for this is that varieties must be distinct before they receive PVR. Maintaining a large reference collection is expensive, particularly so when many mediocre varieties are listed and not in everyday trade. The reduction in the reference collection would be achieved by: (i) introducing a fee to keep varieties on the national list; (ii) re-evaluating variety VCU and only listing the top 25 percent7. 170. The Seed Certification Division, would be fully responsible for the monitoring of production quality and health in the field and processing centers and for issuing of all plant material related certificates. Quality control for the bulk of the harvested seed is presently checked by seed trade laboratories, usually at their processing plants. This is a very satisfactory system and should be maintained. Again, the NSA seed quality control laboratory (NSA central services) would be the final arbiter on all questions of seed quality and health. This laboratory would train and license seed analysts and monitor licensed seed trade laboratories. The Division would be totally responsible for controlling the issue of licenses and the maintenance of standards. Individuals would pay to attend the training courses and for the license, thus the training element should be self-financing. BENEFITS AND BENEFICIARIES 176. The major benefits from the reorganization of the plant industry regulatory and quality control services would include: (i) rapid introduction of a range of modem varieties (protected by PVR) into Croatian agriculture; (ii) the improvement of seed quality to the farmer, this would ultimately allow a reduction of 20-30 percent in the sowing rate; (iii) an increase in farm outputs. The program should add 10 percent to the national production in maize; (iv) a reduction in seed prices through increased competition; (v) an improvement in the organization, administration and cost effectiveness of the regulatory and quality control network, with consequent improved access to export markets. 177. The main beneficiaries would be: (i) farmer would benefit the most through improved income from reduced seed use and higher yielding, more efficient varieties;

 Project Implementation Plan - 103 - ANNEX A Vm. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION FOR POLICY ANALYSIS UNIT 187. Parliament's adoption of the Government's "Agricultural Policy Strategy" has paved the way for widespread policy reform over the next 2-3 years. The MAF's capacity for policy analysis and policy formation is rather limited however, consisting of a unit of two people which reports to the Deputy Minister, Agriculture Policy. Neither of these people are well-trained in the techniques of policy analysis. 188. Recognizing this deficiency, the MAF has now received permission to increase this unit to 4-5 people and has the project support which would establish an effective Agriculture Policy Analysis Unit. The proposed role, structure and organization of this Agriculture Policy Analysis Unit (APAU) are outlined below, together with a description of the technical assistance requested from the Project. This technical assistance has been designed to meet both the immediate needs of MAF to develop the policies needed to implement the Agricultural Policy Strategy, and the more fundamental long-term need to establish a strong national policy capacity for policy analysis. A. ROLE FOR THE MAF POLICY UNIT 189. Price and trade policy is viewed as the most appropriate focus of the Policy Unit. As the Croatian economy becomes more open and market-oriented, a strong capacity for price and trade policy analysis would become increasingly important in order to provide effective advice on: - the implications of policy change for Croatian farmers, processors and consumers of agricultural products. - the form which current and future price and trade policies should take 190. To fulfill this general mandate, MAF would establish a APAU which reports to the Deputy Minister responsible for economic policy. Working together with the Minister and Deputy-Ministers of Agriculture, and national and international experts, the specific responsibilities of the APAU would be to: - Provide advice on the price and trade policy measures required to implement the agricultural strategy, and the timing of any policy changes. - Assist in the preparation, negotiation and re-negotiation of trade agreements which effect the agricultural sector. - Monitor trends in domestic and international markets for those agricultural inputs and outputs relevant to Croatian agriculture, and advise the MAF on the implications of these trends for agricultural production and trade. - Monitor trends in domestic agricultural production and agro-processing and advise the MAF on the implications of these trends for agricultural production and trade. - Monitor trends in those macroeconomic conditions which influence production, processing, prices and trade (inflation, exchange rates, interest rates, economic growth etc) - Monitor proposed policy changes in other sectors of the economy and advise the MAF on the implications of these policies for agricultural production and trade.
 ANNEX A - 104 - Project Implementation Plan - Maintain effective links with the agricultural research community and the Agricultural Research Council. B. STRUCTURE OF THE POLICY UNIT 191. The unit would comprise 4-5 people working under a unit head, who would report to the Deputy Minister responsible for economic policy. In addition to the head person, the unit would require three- four specialists to work in the following subject areas: - International Trade and Prices - Farm Management and Farm Surveys - Domestic Marketing, Consumption and Agro-Processing - Information Acquisition, Management and Dissemination; and Administrative Support. 192. In addition to their specific responsibilities, all the staff of the Policy Unit would need to be computer literate, particularly with word-processing and the use of spread-sheets, and have the ability and the desire to learn new approaches to economic analysis quickly. C. JOB DESCRIPTIONS AND QUALIFICATIONS OF POLICY UNIT STAFF Policy Unit Head 193. The Policy Unit Head would have overall responsibility for using resources within the unit to review the implications of current and future policies relevant to the agricultural sector, and advising the Minister and Deputy-Minister on the form and timing of any policy changes under review. To fulfill this role he or she would have the following responsibilities: 194. Responsibilities: - Collaborate with the Minister and Deputy Minister in selecting the policy issues to be examined and monitored by the Policy Unit - Allocate these studies and responsibilities to appropriate staff within the Policy Unit and advise on the most appropriate methodologies and sources of data to use, and the time-frame in which the work should be completed. - Where necessary, take responsibility for the final analysis and report (in the event that the level of analysis required exceeds the skills of the staff allocated to the study). - Contract required studies to domestic and international agencies as necessary. - Monitor trends and events within and outside the agricultural sector (both in and outside Croatia) and report to the Minister and Deputy-Minister on their implications for agricultural policy. 195. Qualifications: - Post-graduate qualification in economics, agricultural economics or a related discipline; an understanding of market-oriented economic policies and modern approaches to price and trade policy analysis; experience in staff management.

International Trade and Price Specialist: 196. Responsibilities: - Monitor trends in prices, quantities and trading patterns in world markets for relevant agricultural inputs and outputs, and advise the Unit Head on the implications of these trends. - Provide information as required on future world prices, based on projections published by the World Bank, FAO, OECD and the EU. - Where required, use conventional partial equilibrium analysis techniques to determine the economic and welfare implications of different forms and levels of price support. - Monitor trends in agricultural imports and exports and advise the Unit Head on the implications of these trends. - Understand all current and pending bilateral and multilateral trade agreements which affect the agricultural sector, and advise the Unit Head on factors relevant to the negotiation or re- negotiation of these agreements 197. Qualifications: - Graduate or post-graduate qualification in economics or agricultural economics, with particular emphasis on price and trade policy. - A knowledge of partial-equilibrium analysis, and world trade in agricultural inputs and outputs. - A knowledge of Croatia's current price policy, agricultural trade and the implications of future membership of the WTO and the EU. - The willingness and ability to learn and apply new approaches to policy analysis. Farm Management and Farm Survey Specialist: 198. Responsibilities: - Monitor trends in farm output and input prices and their impact on farm production and profitability, and advise the Unit Head on the implications of these trends. - Monitor trends in farm production and the allocation of land to different enterprises, and advise the Unit Head on the implications of these trends. - In conjunction with other relevant groups, plan and coordinate farm surveys and collate the information collected in order to provide a comprehensive data base on farm households and enterprises. - Based on this survey data and other relevant information, prepare and regularly update enterprise and full-farm budgets for all types of farmers in selected locations, as the basis for reviewing on-farm opportunities and constraints. - Meet regularly with farmers and extension agents in order to keep informed of the opportunities and constraints faced by farmers, and the impact of policy change; and advise the Unit Head on types of information and analyses which would improve the ability of the Policy Unit to examine these issues.

D. STAFF TRAINING 204. Each of the 4-5 staff members would receive up to three months training outside Croatia, in their field of specialization. Potential training programs include those offered by the Economic Development Institute, World Bank (USA); the Harvard Institute of International Development, Harvard University (USA); and Wye College, England. In the course of normal work for the Policy Unit additional experience should also be sought from attendance at policy seminars and visits to international organizations, within and outside Croatia. 205. F. AGRICULTURE PRICE AND TRADE SPECLILIST 217. Background. As the Croatian economy becomes more open and market-oriented, price and trade policy will become increasingly important. A strong capacity for price and trade analysis is thus essential in order to provide effective advice on: - the implications of policy change for Croatian farmers and processors and Croatian consumers of agricultural products; and - the form which current and future price and trade policies should take.
 ANNEX A -110 - Project Implementation Plan 218. To fulfill this general mandate the MAF proposes to establish an Agriculture Policy Unit which reports to the Deputy Minister of Agriculture responsible for economic policy. Working together with the Minister and Deputy-Ministers of Agriculture, and national and experts, the specific responsibilities of this Policy Unit would be to: - Provide advice on the price and trade policy measures required to implement MAF's Agricultural Policy Strategy, and the timing of any policy changes. - Assist in the preparation, negotiation and re-negotiation of trade agreement effect the agricultural sector. - Monitor trends in domestic and international markets for those agriculture inputs and outputs relevant to Croatian agriculture, and advise the MAF on the implication of these trends for agricultural production and trade. - Monitor trends in domestic agricultural production and agro-processing and advice the MAF on the implications of these trends for agricultural production. - Monitor trends in macroeconomic conditions which influence production, processing, prices and trade (inflation, exchange rates, interest rates, economic growth); - Monitor proposed policy changes in other sectors of the economy and advise MAF on the implications of these policies for agricultural production and trade. 219. Assignent. As it will take some time to staff and equip the Policy Unit, more immediate technical assistance is needed to begin the policy reforms specified in MAF's Agriculture Policy Strategy. Among the most pressing of these reforms are those associated with trade and price policy as a result of pending membership of the World Trade Organization and the proposed rationalization of import protection and price support. Rapid, well-conceived policy initiatives in these areas will also do much to sustain the widespread initial support for the Agriculture Policy Strategy and to assist in the restructuring of MAF's Agriculture Policy Unit. 220. To support the analysis, choice and design of these reforms, and the concurrent negotiation and re-negotiation of major trade agreements, a consultant will be employed as soon as possible for a period of about two months to provide expertise on a short-term basis. The consultant will work in the current Policy Department in the MAF and report to the Deputy Minister responsible for Economic Policy. The MAF will provide the consultant with an office, computer facilities, and full logistical support. 221. Responsibilities and Output. (i) To advise the Deputy Minister on all aspects of price and trade policy, with emphasis on the impact of membership to the World Trade Organization, rationalization of import protection and price support, and the negotiation of major trade agreements. (ii) To prepare short written reports on all analyses undertaken in this regard for future reference by Policy Unit Staff. These reports should describe the issue analyzed, the methodology applied, and any assumptions used; followed by discussion of the recommendation 222. Qualifications: Post-graduate qualification in Agricultural Economics or Economics (minimum Master Level) with at least ten years of relevant work experience in the analysis of price and trade. A sound knowledge of the World Trade Organization and the technical aspects of the Uruguay Round Agreement; the trade implications of the Common Agricultural Policy of the European Union; and an understanding of the process of negotiating trade agreements. An understanding of the problems faced by economies in transition, preferably in eastern and central Europe. A sound grasp of the principles and techniques of economic analysis and the ability to apply these skills to the analysis of price and trade policy and to communicate the associated methodology and results.
 Project hIplementation Plan - 111 - ANNEX A G. MARKET INFORMATION SYSTEM 223. Background. Full access to information is an essential pre-requisite for an efficient, agricultural sector, especially if family farms are to benefit from the opportunities created by well-functioning markets. With this in mind, a market information system (MIS) is to be established within MAF's APAU. The objective is to collect information at approximately ten produce markets throughout Croatia on a daily basis which would be transmitted to Zagreb by computer for collation and then disseminated through daily radio broadcasts. 224. A series of short-term technical inputs would be required to establish the MIS and to review its initial performance. These inputs would be provided by a Market Information Specialist and a Communications Specialist who would be employed for 7 weeks and 2 weeks respectively over a total elapsed time of approximately 5 months. Their respective activities and responsibilities are specified below. 225. The technical assistance would involve an initial visit by the market information specialist and the communication specialists to design the system, arrange the radio broadcasts, and define the technical specifications of the equipment. Once the hardware and software have been obtained during early project implementation, the communications specialist would return to install it and check that it was operating correctly. The market information specialist would then train the enumerators responsible for data collection and MAF's market policy analyst responsible for data collation, and ensure that they were able to operate the equipment. Three months after the system has been in operation the market information specialist would return for a further two weeks to review the system and assess the need and nature of any improvements. 226. Detailed Assignments for the Market Information Specialist and the Communications Specialist A. System Design - Choose market sites and commodities (types and quality) - Determine which information to collect (prices, quantities, quality, origin of produce etc) - Design and produce questionnaires or survey instruments - Determine technical specifications of hard and software in collaboration with MAF's Information officer - Develop methodology for data collection - Establish a format for collating and summarizing the data at the Policy Unit - Initiate recruitment of enumerators (desired qualifications, amount of work required etc) - Determine optimal broadcasting procedures Time Required: 1 month for the Market Information Specialist, two weeks for the Communications Specialist. Output: The output of the design stage would consist in a systematic operational handbook, discussed and agreed upon with MAF covering all procedural aspects of the market information system, and including technical specifications of the hard and software to be procured under the project.

Review system after three months of operation - Review response to mnarket information provided and perceptions of its usefulness. - Recommend changes to the type of information collected, and the manner of collection and dissemination as considered appropriate. Time Required: 1 week for the Market Information Specialist Output: Evaluation Report 227. Qualifications: Market Information Specialist: Degree in (agriculture) marketing (minimnum Master level) or related fields and at least ten years relevant experience in market intelligence. Communications Specialist: technical expert in data transfer and processing technology with at least ten years relevant experience. H. FARM MONITORING SURVEYS 228. Background. Prior to independence the collection of agricultural statistics was oriented towards production on ex-social sector farms. The consequent lack of information on private farms has become a serious constraint to policy analysis, especially following the adoption of a new Agricultural Policy Strategy which emphasizes the role of family farms. It is difficult to respond effectively to the needs of Croatia's small-scale family farms when so little is known about the constraints they face and implications of policy change for their well-being. To address this problem the project would initiate and fund two related surveys, each of which covers both full and part-time small-scale family farms. The first would be a comprehensive baseline survey to provide up-to-date information on factors such demographic characteristics, the farm resource base, cropping patterns and livestock holdings, levels of production and marketed surplus, the level and composition of farm income and expenditure, and the contribution of non-farm income to total household income. It would also include behavioral and attitudinal variables. A smaller, second survey would then be initiated as the basis for an annual monitoring of the status of and the changes on family farms. This second survey would be of a size (in terms of both numbers and data collected) which allows rapid data collection, processing and analysis. The two surveys would be designed together to ensure that they complement each other as much as possible. 229. Technical assistance for these surveys would consist of an agriculture statistician and a farm management survey specialist. Particular emphasis would be placed on involving members of the MAF,
 Project Implementation Plan - 113 - ANNEX A the Institute of Agriculture Economics and family farmer representatives in the initial design of the two surveys. To ensure that the information generated informs policy decisions in a timely manner, careful attention should also be given to procedures which allow quick and effective data processing. Such timeliness will be especially important for the smaller annual monitoring surveys. 230. The duties and responsibilities of the respective consultants are outlined below. An input of two weeks is envisaged for the agricultural statistician and six weeks for the farm management survey specialist. The MAF would provide office space and logistical support to each consultant. 231. Output of the overall assignment: The output of the study would consist in a systematic operational handbook, discussed and agreed upon with MAF covering all procedural aspects of the baseline and the on-farm monitoring system. 232. Agriculture Statistician Responsibilities: - together with the Croatian Bureau of Statistics, review the national sampling framework and develop recommendations on optimal sampling procedures and sample sizes for both the baseline survey and the annual monitoring surveys. - review the current definitions of full and part-time farmers used in the national sampling framework. Decide on their relevance to the two surveys and recommend alternative definitions where appropriate, plus measures to modify the sampling framework accordingly. - for the monitoring survey review the implications of taking a new sample each year or retaining a fixed sample and re-weighing it each year to reflect changes in the underlying population. Describe the sampling techniques to be used in the event that a new sample is taken each year, and the basis for re-weighing the sample in the event that a fixed sample is considered optimal. - prepare a report of not more than twenty pages which describes the national sampling framework, its suitability as the basis for the proposed farm surveys, the definitions of full a part- time farmers, and the sampling procedures and sample sizes considered optimal for each of the two surveys. Include the description and discussion of the alternative sampling strategies for the monitoring surveys. Time allowed for the study and report writing, two weeks. Qualifications: Advanced degree in agricultural statistics or statistics (minimum Masters Level), with at least ten years experience in the statistical design of both large and small-scale surveys of small farmers.

Ensure that the two sets of questionnaires generate data which are consistent and can be used in a complementary manner. - for the monitoring survey questionnaire, ensure that one element of the data set is quantitative and constant, to provide a consistent source of time-series data; and another more flexible module collects on issues of current importance. (for example the use of a permanent module on factors such as resource use, cropping patterns and livestock holdings, production levels and marketed surplus; plus a qualitative module which varies from year to year in response to particular issues of importance). - determine the most appropriate definitions of full and part-time farmers based on the report by the agricultural statistician and discussions with Croatian collaborators. - based on the sampling strategies recommended by the agricultural statistician, develop a cost- effective strategy for sample selection for each survey, which facilitates accurate, efficient collection. include consideration of interviews, mail surveys, and the payment of farmers to keep their won records and complete their own questionnaires. - develop data entry and verification routines in association with questionnaire design, to sure that the data are entered and checked in a timely manner; and make realistic estimates of the time and resources required to transform the raw data into a form useful for analysis. - advise on the most appropriate basis for analysis of the data from each survey, and prepare an outline report (including dummy tables), to guide final analysis and ensure that the results illuminate the issues originally defined. - for each survey prepare a realistic timetable for survey implantation and data processing and analysis. - prepare a report which summarizes the issues to be addressed by the two surveys, the sampling strategies and data collection and processing techniques to be used, the implementation timetables, and the outline of the analysis. Time required to complete the study, including report writing: six weeks. Qualifications: (i) Advanced degree in agriculture economics (minimum Master level) with a specialization in farm management, and (ii) at least ten years experience in the design, implementation and analysis of farm management surveys.  REPUBLIC OF CROATIA FARMERS SUPPORT SERVICES PROJECT ANNEX C PROJECT PROCUREMENT ARRANGEMENTS 1. Project procurement arrangements are summarized in the Table C. 1 below and will be undertaken in the following manner: (i) Procurement of goods. The purchase of vehicles; computers; seed, grassland, and veterinary laboratory equipment (excluding applied research related equipment; see below, Procurement of Research Services); specialized farming equipment (for seed and pasture variety trials); and milk and meat quality testing equipment would be carried out through International Competitive Bidding (ICB) procedures in accordance with the Bank's "Guidelines for Procurement Under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits" (January 1995). Contracts for goods estimated to cost US$300,000 or above would be procured through ICB. Goods procured through ICB would constitute about 90 percent of cost of Loan-financed goods. In the evaluation and comparison of bids for equipment to be procured through ICB, Croatian manufactures would receive a domestic preference in bid evaluation of 15 percent of the CIF price or the prevailing customs duty, whichever is less, provided that a bidder offering goods manufactured in Croatia establishes to the satisfaction of the Borrower and the Bank that (i) labor, raw materials and components from within Croatia will account for more than 30 percent of the Ex-Works price of the product offered; and (ii) the production facility in which those goods will be manufactured or assembled has been engaged in manufacturing / assembling such goods at least since the time of bid submission. (ii) The remaining 10 percent of Loan funded goods would be in minor packages suitable for procurement methods other than ICB as follows: (a) National Competitive Bidding (NCB) for office furniture: two contracts (financing amounting to approximately US$470,000) would be concluded using Bank's NCB bidding documents for goods; there are numerous national manufactures and traders of office furniture in Croatia ensuring competition in the provision of these goods; also the size and the nature of the contracts is not likely to generate foreign interest in bidding; (b) contracts for goods estimated to cost less than US$50,000 per contract (financing amounting to US$280,000 in the aggregate), including audio-visual equipment, small-scale irrigation equipment, herd performance recording equipment, and off- the-shelf items such as office and training supplies, may be purchased through National Shopping (NS), obtaining price quotations from at least three qualified local suppliers; and

 Project Implementation Plan - 129 - ANNEX C (iii) Procurement of works. Two civil works contracts would be carried out, consisting (i) of the rehabilitation of the Sljeme Pasture Research Station, and the construction of the Pasture Laboratory and Training Facility at said station; and (ii) the installation of a small seed bank at the Faculty of Agronomy, University of Zagreb. The first contract (i.e., construction and rehabilitation of Sljeme Pasture Research Station, estimated to cost US$904,000 (financing US$796,000), would be procured following National Competitive Bidding (NCB) procedures in accordance with Bank Procurement Guidelines. The issue of prequalifications would be discussed at negotiations. The second civil works contract (i.e., installation of a gene bank), estimated to cost US$56,000 (financing US$49,000), would be done following National Shopping procedures for small works based on price quotations from at least three local qualified contractors. The local construction industry is qualified to carry out such relatively simple civil works; also, it has been established that sufficient competition exists amongst the local suppliers of civil works. Given the remote location of the Sljeme Pasture Research Station, and the small value of the second contract, it would not be likely to attract foreign bidders. A Country Procurement Assessment Review (CPAR) for Croatia will be done following the passage by Parliament of its Public Procurement Law. The CPAR is tentatively scheduled for early 1996. Meanwhile, the Bank's NCB bidding documents for works will be used for the above -mentioned NCB contract. (iv) Procurement of consulting services. Consultants for specialized and professional services financed under the project would be selected in accordance with the Guidelines for the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the Bank as Executing Agency (August 1981). These services will be procured on the basis of shortlisting of qualified well-known firms, both international and local. With the exception of a long term agriculture policy specialists, all individual consultancy assignments are of a short term nature (between one to three months) and many include the development of training programs and curricula. 2. Specialized services would include six consulting contracts (estimated total cost US$1.84 million) for each of the project components. Each contract to be executed by international and national consultants would include the following specialized services: (i) extension: extension specialists, and skills training specialist; (ii) research: applied research management specialist, applied research training specialist, specialized agriculture research advisors; (iii) animal health: veterinary epidemiologist, epidemiology data base specialist, whole herd health advisor, computer programmer; (iv) grassland development: pasture resource inventory specialist, pasture/livestock economist, grassland management specialist, pasture-based ruminant nutrition specialist; (v) seed industry development: seed certification specialist, seed industry regulations specialist, seed testing and trials specialists; and (vi) policy analysis support: agriculture policy specialist, trade analyst, subsector policy specialists and policy studies; and farm monitoring and market information activities. 3. Included under item (vi) para. 2 above (policy analysis support) but under separate procurement arrangements are farm monitoring activities (aggregate finance US$100,000) and the implementation of a market information system (aggregate finance US$100,000). Farm monitoring activities including a baseline survey, and an annual farm survey would be commissioned directly from the Institute of Agriculture Economic, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Zagreb. The Institute of Agriculture Economics is currently the only entity in Croatia to have the experience, staff and capacity to carry out detailed empirical work in rural areas. MAF would implement the Market Information
 ANNEX C - 130 - Project Implementation Plan System through its Agriculture Policy Analysis Unit. The required TA, overseas training and computing equipment for the establishment of the Market Information System would be procured through shortlisting from a single qualified consulting firm. 4. National advisors would be hired by private farmer associations under the Farmer Association Advisor Pilot Scheme. Sufficient private sector advisors with the required qualifications are available in Croatia because of their redundancy caused by the dismantling of the ex-social sector agro-kombinats and will provide adequate competition. The advisors would be procured through advertising in the local press. The advertisements announcing the need of the advisors will include their terns of reference, based on standard terms of reference which will be reviewed by the Bank. MAF would prepare these standard terms of reference and will submit them to the Bank for its review, prior to the publications of advertisements. The appointment of the candidate selected by the farmer association would be subject to MAF's approval. 5. Procurement of training services and materials. To the extent feasible external fellowships and training programs shall be included as part of the technical assistance packages procured from consulting firms and training institutions; otherwise external fellowships and training would be awarded on a direct contract basis with foreign institutions selected by MAF with the prior approval of the Bank. In service, local training would be carried out by MAF, ARC, NVI, and NSA directly, or in collaboration with national institutions on the basis of shortlisting with the assistance of the consultant experts mentioned above. Prior to the beginning of it's fiscal year, during the life of the project, MAF would prepare and submit to the Bank a detailed training and fellowship program for its review and approval. 6. Training materials which the Bank agrees are of a proprietary nature (e.g. technical publications and journals/reference materials, computer software, etc.), may be acquired through Direct Contracting from proprietors and/or copyright holders, in accordance with procedures acceptable to the Bank. The aggregate financing of training materials procured through Direct Contracting amounts to approximately US$340,000. Development and publication of a farm management handbook, a veterinary journal, and approximately 30 extension mass media packages (aggregate amount financed approximately US$370,000) would be done on the basis of National Shopping. 7. Procurement of research services. The ARC would award research contracts (estimated to range from US$50,000 to US$150,000) under a competitive grant arrangement financed from the Agriculture Research Fund supported by the Bank's Loan. The ARC would make public invitations for research proposals, specifying the type of research, the methodology, and the scope of research work to be carried out. Qualified national research organizations and enterprises (both public and private sector) are eligible to submit research proposals which will be judged with the support of independent reviewers, consisting of a team of experts from MOST under the responsibility of ARC, on their technical merit and price competitiveness, and the contract will be awarded by the ARC. MOST would be responsible for supervising the contracted research services. Laboratory and analytical equipment would be included into the research proposal and would become a factor of evaluation of proposals. For the implementation of this component a detailed operational manual would be prepared by MAF with the technical assistance financed under a Japanese Grant Fund; MAF would submit this manual to the Bank for review to meet the condition of disbursement under this component. 8. Incremental operating costs. Incremental operating costs would be fully financed by Government with recurrent cost items procured in accordance with regular Government procedures.
 Project Implementation Plan - 131 - ANNEX C 9. Procurement Review. The Bank would conduct a prior review of all ICB package and all the first NCB and NS procurement packages for civil works, and the first NCB for goods. Prior Bank approval would also be sought for all direct contracting. In addition, prior review would be undertaken for all consulting contracts above US$100,000 (firms) and US$50,000 (individuals). The Bank's standard bidding documents would be used for ICB packages and for the recruitment of consultants. 10. Procurement information to be provided by the Borrower. The Borrower would promptly inform the Bank of contract award and procurement issues and would include the following procurement information in its progress reports: (a) for equipment/materials, work contracts, technical assistance, training and study tours: status and timing of all pending activities; and (b) status of aggregate limits on specified methods of procurement.

 REPUBLIC OF CROATIA FARMERS SUPPORT SERVICES PROJECT ANNEX E SUMMARY FARM MODEL AND PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS I. INTRODUCTION 1. During project preparation in June 1994 nine farm models were constructed so as to: * illustrate and check the likely farm level technical and production impacts of project activities such as improved extension, research,veterinary services and input(seed) supply. * assess the financial viability of the new technical options in a range of farming systems and locations. v assess the economic implications of the expected changes. At appraisal in March 1995, five of these models were selected and updated. This annex describes and presents the results of the analysis of these five models. The remaining four models are available on diskette; they are not considered here so as to avoid undue complexity. Staff of the Institute of Agricultural Economics, Faculty of Agronomy, University of Zagreb, participated actively in the specification and analysis of the models. The University has a regular farm survey program and completed additional interviews to check data used in the models with farmers and processors. In particular, Mr. J. Kraljickovic and Mr. J. Juracak contributed much of the data needed to build the models. 2. The models are indicative and it is believed that they reflect changes which are likely to occur on farms which are exposed to more focused extension services and have access to improved management advice, seed, livestock and other inputs. Details of the models summarized here are given in Annex N of the supplemental volume. II. MODEL DESCRIPTIONS A. GENERAL 3. The project aims to strengthen support services to farmers which will enable them to improve production efficiency, management and marketing. The project will help farmers to focus on the farm as a business and to respond to market changes by varying activity patterns and input levels, as well as improving technical efficiency. The key to this approach is an effective extension service with a commercial orientation and access to quality research and technical services.
 ANNEX E - 142 - Project Implementation Plan 4. The crop and livestock budgets which form the basis of each farm or household model were prepared in consultation with local agronomists and economists and checked by field discussion with farmers, where possible. Generally they postulate crop yield increases of about 15 per cent with project and include higher fertilizer, better seed inputs and improved livestock rations. Farm size has been held constant between without and with project situations, although there are changes in cropping patterns with project. The impact of investment to expand farm size, buy additional machinery or livestock or to install irrigation, is examined separately in the proposed Rural Finance Pilot Project. Model farm size is typically in the range 5 to 7 ha (except for intensive Dalmatia Vegetable model). This is a little larger than average private farm size in these regions but there are many such farms and it is considered that they are likely to respond first to improved support services. 5. Most of the options available within FARMOD to model household level estimates were used to provide a comprehensive description and assessment. Labor budgets show substantial annual surpluses of family labor in all models, without and with project. Seasonal peaks in labor demand require use of hired labor in the intensive vegetable models and most models do require incremental family labor with project. Household consumption of farm produce has been included in each model and meets staple grain, milk, egg and meat needs in most cases (exception high value vegetable model). Farm families will have to draw upon the cash surpluses shown in each model to cover other food and living expenses. Overhead costs are also included in each model to cover business expenses not readily allocated to individual crop or livestock enterprises. Such costs are mostly in the range US$1,450 to US$1,800 per farm and cover electricity, other fuel, land tax and insurance, tractor and equipment services and labor, not related to individual crop activities. 6. Very few private farms in Croatia have access to short or long term credit and so the financing of production inputs in these models follows reality as both without and with project situations 100 per cent of operating costs are financed by retained farm earnings from the previous year. Incremental production costs typically lie in the range US$715 to US$2,200 per farm, or a little under half of the expected gross value of incremental revenue. This is within the capacity of most model farms to finance, either from without project retained earnings, from off-farm income or by moving to the with project situation in steps over two or three years. 7. Each model attempts to meet it's livestock feed needs from on-farm forage and crop production, in line with usual practice in Croatia. There are exceptions for the vegetable model and some feed additives and concentrates. Each model represents an individual farm and the with project situation has not been phased in. The nature of most of the new technology proposed is such (better seeds, additional fertilizer) that it is likely to be accepted promptly when the benefits are demonstrated clearly. 8. The following five models are described in more detail below: * Istria Mixed Farm Model * Dalmatia Vegetable Farm Model * Lika Mixed Farm Model * Slavonija Crop Farm Model * West Continental Dairy/Beef Farm Model
 Project Implementation Plan - 143 - ANNEX E B. SPEcIc Istria Mixed Farm Model 9. This model may be applied to farms in the central area of the Istrian peninsular. Farms in this area have opportunities to supply the local tourist industry and closer commercial ties to neighboring countries than some other parts of Croatia. The model has a cropped area of 7.1 ha in both project situations. The with project cropping pattern expands higher return potato and lucerne production and deletes wheat and maize production so as to avoid large increments in labor or land use. Improved technology is applied to barley, potato and lucerne production in the with project situation. Istria traditionally provides hay and forage seeds to adjacent mountain areas and has adequate markets for increased potato production. Although livestock activities comprise almost half of the gross value of production no incremental livestock income is assumed, as it focuses on higher value crops. 10. Family labor requirements increase from 1,220 hours per year to 1,410 hours with project, an increment of 190 hours. This still leaves a large surplus which can be used in part to gain employment in the tourist industry. Dalmatia Vegetable Farm Model 11. Dalmatia has a successful and expanding vegetable industry in part due to a warmer climate which enables early harvest and access to high price, out-of-season markets in other parts of Croatia and nearby countries. One of the main limits to expansion of production is a shortage of irrigation water and investment to make better use of water is examined separately in the proposed Rural Finance Project. No such investment is considered in this project. Joint marketing of vegetables is also being explored by farmers in Dalmatia. 12. This model has a small farm area of 1.2 ha but has by far the highest net value of production of any model due to the focus on early tomato and potato crops and other vegetables. There are no changes of cropping pattern assumed for the with project situation but crop yields are increased by 10 per cent mainly in response to higher fertilizer and manure inputs. Livestock are produced for home consumption and there are no increments with project. 13. Incremental family labor with project (to handle larger harvests) is 191 hour per year. Although there is substantial unused family labor, hired labor is needed to meet seasonal peaks of demand and this also increases with project, by 33 hours per year. Lika Mixed Farm Model 14. Lika is a mountainous area with much pasture land and some emphasis on livestock production. The proposed Rural Finance Pilot Project includes a specialist sheep production model but this model looks at changes in a mixed farm with crop, cattle and pig production. The model increases potato and reduces wheat production with project in response to crop budget financial profitability; additionally dairy cow numbers are increased from 3 to 4 and cheese making (600 kg per year) is introduced with project. Financing is discussed in 3.2.3 below. There is a strong demand for local cheeses and the necessary skills and interest in increasing production are available. Potato and barley yields are increased by about 15 per cent with project in response to use of better seed and more fertilizer.
 ANNEX E - 144 - Project Implementation Plan 15. The cropped area is constant at 5.8 ha in both project situations and is below total farm area of 7.9 ha to allow for rotation and non-arable land. 16. This model has the greatest increment in family labor input with project, 631 hour per year. However with project labor is still only about half estimated available labor and most of the increment is in high value cheese production yielding incremental hourly returns more than double average without project returns. Slavonija Crop Farm Model 17. Slavonija is the major crop production region in Croatia. This model is representative of private farms which are replacing the Agro-Kombinats as major producers in the region. The cropping pattern changes with project to reduce sugar beet and maize area and to expand soybean, so as to improve self- sufficiency in pig feed. Wheat, meadow and barley are constant, as is the total cropped area of 5.3 ha. Almost half of the crops produced (by value) are used on-farm for livestock production. The model includes 1 cow, 6 sows and a small poultry activity (no increment with project). Of these, the pig activity is the main commercial livestock activity; with project weaner pig production increases by about 13 per cent and ration costs are reduced. Crop yield increases of just under 15 per cent are achieved with better fertilizer inputs and seeds. 18. Family labor use in this model is near constant with and without project. The yield increases do not demand additional labor as harvest is mechanized and the changes in cropping pattern do not create new labor demands. West Continental Dairy/Beef Farm Model 19. This model has four Simmental cows in both project situations. Milk production increases from 2,800 1 to 3,360 1 per cow per year with project. Improved animal health, changed rations and better genetic material are expected to be accessible through improved extension and veterinary services. The cropped area remains constant at 4.3 ha but the pattern changes with project. Maize silage and mixed grass pasture are introduced to boost feed supply with project and maize for grain and the less productive meadow are reduced slightly. Mixed grass and other improved pastures would be stimulated by project activities and gradually displace meadow and other unimproved pastures. Further increases in technical and financial performance are possible, e.g. use of milk replacer for calf rearing or breed changes, and practical but have not been considered as they are still uncommon in Croatia. 20. Family labor requirements are virtually the same with and without project and are around 40 per cent of estimated available labor. There is scope to expand the size of farms of this type but this is not considered within this project. Increased farm size plus use of milk replacer would have a big positive impact on milk collection costs and overall dairy industry efficiency. III. FARM MODEL FINANCIAL ANALYSIS A. GENERAL 21. The farm gate fmancial prices used in this analysis are those which prevailed in the main production region for each item during March 1995. Minor seasonal adjustments were made and some averaging was employed where prices differed between main producing regions. All analysis has been

The prices used provide reliable farm gate values for the expected incremental production. This model shows a gross incremental annual production value of US$2,740 on a without project base of US$7,600. Alternative Istrian livestock models could be developed, provided milk and meat markets are established. 24. Incremental cash production costs are US$1,360 per year and this would have to be financed in the first year by off-farm income or phased in over several years. Switching value analysis shows that incremental revenues cold be halved or operating costs rise by 101 per cent before NPV declined to zero. This suggests that the model is robust and capable of absorbing large increases in costs or medium to large falls in revenue, before returns fall below 10 per cent. 26. Annex M presents estimates of economic prices (in terms of nominal protection coefficient - NPC) for key commodities and inputs: wheat, maize, soybeans, sugar beet, milk and fertilizer. The reciprocals of the NPC's of Annex M have been used as conversion factors in FARMOD prices to calculate economic prices for the above items. In all other cases (outputs and inputs) the conversion factor 1.0 has been used, equating financial and economic prices. For these models the other main incremental products(not listed above) are meat and vegetables. Croatia currently engages in only small amounts of international trade in meat and vegetables and there are no major subsidies in place to support their production. In this situation it seems reasonable to accept a NPC of 1.0. Incremental labor has also been valued at market price in the economic analysis although it is likely that economic labor value may be lower in some locations. The five models show a similar distribution of annual economic benefit to that existing in financial terms: three models are similar in size of without project economic benefit (-US$1,800 per year) , the Dalmatia Vegetable Model yields benefits more than ten times larger (US$24,000) and the Istrian model yields a small negative return (-US$190)without project. 41. All models show positive increments in net economic value of production with project and have positive economic Net Production Values (NPVs), usually a little lower than the corresponding financial NPV, at 1995 prices and NPC's. The analysis was for a 10 year period and the discount rate was set at 10 per cent. As changes in policy are implemented it is likely that production shifts will occur to further increase the economic value of incremental production. The Slavonija Crop Farm Model is an

PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. INTRODUCTION 50. Based on the results of the farm model analysis previously discussed, the following economic analysis attempts to quantify the project net incremental economic returns. Quantifying the economic returns of the vast range of project activities including agriculture extension, applied research, animal health, pasture and fodder development, seed industry development, and agriculture policy support is notoriously difficult, given the broad range of non-service factors influencing decision making at the farm level, and uncertainties associated with the translation of improved farm services into economic farn benefits. The purpose of estimating project returns, therefore, is to verify that the project is broadly economically viable and robust to changes in project cost and benefits. The following analysis is based on a number of conservative assumptions discussed below. Economic flows are calculated over a ten year time horizon, albeit benefits are expected to accrue well beyond the tenth year. B. PROJECT INCREMENTAL BENEFITS 51. According to World Bank rules, an Environmental Analysis (EA) is required prior to the implementation of the "Farmer Support Services Project" (FSSP). The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) of the Republic of Croatia assigned this task to an expert team competent in EA questions, consisting of Mr. Ferdo Basic Ph.D., Mr. Zoran Griic Ph.D. - Faculty of Agronomy, University of Zagreb, and Ms. Visnja Jelic-Muck B.Sc., State Directorate for Environment Protection. 2. The team reviewed the project documentation to identify potential positive or negative impacts of FSSP on environment. The EA task can be summarized into a few objectives: * To assess the actual environmental situation, before FSSP implementation, and to identify potential direct and indirect impacts on the environment; and * To review the existing legislation as it relates to the use of agrochemicals, fertilizers, animal feed stuffs and veterinary drugs. 3. It is important to point out that FSSP is, according to the World Bank regulations, a category B project which means that it has a limited impact on the environment. 4. The activities to be implemented under the FSSP have a great importance for the promotion and recognition of ecologically sustainable management of Croatian national resources. 5. In implementing this project, no negative environmental impacts are expected. It is realistic to expect that the effects of some project components will strengthen the notion of sustainable agriculture which combines technologies, policies and activities aimed at integrating socioeconomic principles with environmental concerns so as to simultaneously: maintain or enhance production, minimize risk of diminished food production, protect natural resources and prevent degradation of soil and water quality, all with a view to being economically viable and socially acceptable. 6. This EA does not propose a specific mitigation plan (nor does it cost mitigation efforts) because no direct negative environmental impacts are anticipated in the context of implementing this project. However, as a crucial mitigation activity during the first year of project implementation, MAF would develop special ('best practice') guidelines for its extension service and the farming community in support of the concept and practices of sustainable agriculture and appropriate handling of agriculture chemicals.

An essentially different and more favorable situation is that of fragmented private farms, where traditional production is practiced, with high share of livestock production and common use of farmyard manure. Processes of soil degradation have not been registered, except in cases of wind and water erosion. P2 - Central Pannonian Subregion 18. The production structure in this subregion is dominated by intensive crop farming in the plains, and on all slopes (hill-sides). Vineyard and livestock production is particularly prevalent in the south. The ex-social sector is not extensive and fragmented private farms dominate. Crop production is pervasive with some orchard and vineyard production. In relation to the previous subregion, there is a growing trend in the use of livestock and farmyard manure. Favorable conditions and a prospective development exists for vegetable growing, with irrigation. 19. On soils among the ex-social sector, the processes of anthropogenetic soil degradation is registered, whereas soil among the private sector is considerably more preserved, owing to a higher importance of livestock production and integrated farming. Relief is more complex here, as soil structure is unstable and more vulnerable to erosion by water, compounded also with a high share of maize in crop rotation. That is why particular attention should be given to soil conservation. P3 - Western Pannonian Subregion 20. In this subregion, private, fragmented households clearly predominate. Livestock production is developed to the extent that the support from grazing stock is necessary. Consequently, a significant and untapped potential exits for development of sheep- and goat-breeding. The basic direction for investment has to be into irrigation and drainage for vegetable growing, and considering that the soil is mainly acidic, it should be taken into account that liming needs to carried out regularly to correct the acidic soil. Extraordinarily favorable conditions exist for fruit-and wine growing development as well. 21. One of the ecologically questionable management practices on soils in this subregion is narrow crop rotation in favor of maize, which stimulates erosion, and for which increasing herbicide use is regularly used, contributing to a high persistence in soil, such as in the case of atrazin. 22. Within this subregion there are also concentrated sources of emission of different ecologically risky substances, such as industrial plants in Zagreb, ironworks and petroleum refinery in Sisak and food- processing industries in Vrbovec and Koprivnica. P4 - Northwestern Pannonian Subregion 23. Clearly dominated by private and exceptionally fragmented households, this subregion's arable crop production is oriented towards feed stuff production. An ecologically doubtful management practice here is the high share of maize production within the crop rotation. This is compounded by high rainfalls in Spring combined with a period of black fallow soil, and also because crop stands are too thin to cover and protect the soil. 24. Soils in this region require conservation measures such as in drainage in the Varazdin region and irrigation in the Medjimurie region. In addition, the especially valuable use of liming is implemented regularly and systematically. This area is very densely populated and households are highly fragmented. The social sector is negligibly small.
 Project Implementation Plan - 159 - ANNEX F Mountain Region 25. This region comprises 14.2% of the total area, and involves the thinly populated Pery Mountain and Pery Mountain subregions. Mainly wooded areas with little agricultural land, traditional and extensive production exists only on private and poor households. Soil is completely preserved from any form of degradation or damage, except natural erosion. The virgin nature has crystal-clear and beautiful rivers which are of an exceptional quality for irrigation. GI - Pery Mountain Subregion 26. Production capabilities of this area are potentially huge, but totally unused. Especially favorable conditions exist for the development of livestock production, indeed for all forms of ecological agriculture. Almost without exception, soils require liming, and drainage in water-carrying valleys as well. A possible vegetable production orientation would require irrigation, for which extraordinary conditions exist here. Potential hydroelectric development among the pristine rivers would open the way for irrigation. G2 - Mountain Subregion 27. This subregion is mountainous, built mostly of Mesozoic limestones and dolomite of high cleanliness. Silicate sandstone and metamorphic rocks are also present. The subregion is characterized by a mountain climate, with great amounts of precipitation causing erosion and acidification. A frost-free period is short, so the selection of crops is narrowed to those resistant to a very unfavorable climate conditions, like rye and potato. Favorable conditions exist for production of seed-potato which could be produced in quantities exceeding Croatian needs and merit further attention. Beside investments in irrigation, there is need to finance agro-technical soil melioration, particularly calcification. 28. Private ownership is fragmented, with a prevailing orientation towards livestock production, particularly sheep- and goat-breeding. Given the clear beautiful rivers, the national park of the Plitvice Lakes located in this area, as well as botanical preserves and natural gardens, conditions are exceptionally favorable for tourism. Mediterranean Region 29. This region comprises 31.6% of Croatia's coastal area and islands, and is quite diverse in soil and climate characteristics. MI - Northern Mediterranean Subregion 30. This subregion involves the northern coastal area and north littoral islands. It differs from other subregions in that it has a relatively large soil area on a flysh deposit subject to erosion to a serious degree. Efficient soil protection is a precondition to any agricultural production in this area. 31. Soils of this subregion are highly productive, given the favorable climatic conditions (warm temperatures), and a valuable substratum for agricultural production, particularly with regard to Mediterranean crops such as olives, grapes, almonds, peaches, nectarines, mandarins, and also high quality vegetables, for which irrigation would, however, be necessary.
 ANNEX F - 160 - Project Implementation Plan 32. Private farms are small and fragmented, and use of the high production potentials is minimal. A basic limiting factor is unfavorable distribution of rainfall and the typical summer droughts. Any investment here would have to include irrigation for which there is enough water. M2 - Central Mediterranean Subregion 33. This region includes the central part of the coast, with continental background and the belonging islands. It is this area that exemplifies the traditionally developed agriculture such as wine- growing, fruit-growing, vegetable-and flower-growing both on fields and in glass-houses. 34. It is expected that investments to ameliorate irrigation systems will take place. The ex-social sector is relatively highly represented in this area. The typical, geomorphological units, so-called Karst field, with its deep and productive soil, is extremely drained. These are usually flooded during the autumn and winter period and in summer period without rain, the water level falls into Karst subsurface. Because Karst areas are especially sensitive, usage of agro-chemicals has to be extremely rational and of the mobile variety. Persistent pesticides must be avoided, with regard to quantity and timing. Adversely, use of persistent pesticides might come to contaminate soil and waters of the area, with serious consequences for a even wider area. Agriculture production in the wider area of Vransko Lake deserves particular attention, especially considering the different potential uses of such a valuable water resource. M3 - Southlern Mediterranean Subregion 35. Ex-social sector representation is negligible in this subregion. More common are small privately-owned plots. Common Mediterranean crops are mandarins, olives, figs, but also peaches, and cherries and all kinds of vegetables and flowers on fields and in sheltered areas (glass-houses). A c.ommon characteristic of all products from this area is their high quality. Investments are necessary, inter alia, in irrigation, and special importance should also be given to island revitalization. 36. Specially valuable and ecologically sensitive units within this subregion is the river and valley of Neretva, where fertile soil can be found, along with plenty of sunny days, the Mediterranean climate, and plenty of high-quality water. Skilled and hardworking farmers there practice very intensive growing of all Meditecranean crops such as mandarins, vine and vegetables. Because of regular usage of large quantities of various agrochemicals, there are some signs of disturbances in the locally sensitive ecosystems. B. ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BY OWNERSHIP 37. Applied cultivation operations in Croatian agriculture have influenced, inter alia, soils and water. The direction and intensity of that influence is sharply different with regard to farm ownership; there are negative influences on soil and water in the ex-social sector, while there is little or no negative influence among the private sector. 38. Again, due to the absence of reliable data it is not possible to provide a full quantified assessment within the scope of this EA of the impact of different farm types as well as the impact of the project on environmental conditions.
 Project Implementation Plan - 161 - ANNEX F Ex-social Sector 39. With regard to soils within the ex-social sector, all intensive agricultural operations have been carried out, involving usage of large quantities of agrochemicals (mineral fertilizers, pesticides, esp. herbicides including those of the atrazin group), and processes of anthropogene soil and subsurface water degradation have been registered. Among these are: Anthropogenic soil compaction and structural damage due to: * overtillage, using heavy machinery; * tillage in improper moisture conditions; and * unfavorable changes of organic matter regime (lack of soil structure forming and stabilizing agents). Decrease of humus content and humus quality due to * improper recycling of organic residues; * lack of organic fertilizers; and * soil acidification (leaching, mineral and liquid fertilizers, acidic depositions, air pollution), and biological degradation (undesirable changes in microbial populations: total number, species, activity). Soil and water pollution due to: * absorbed and insoluble P compounds transported by surface runoff directly to surface water result in increasing eutrophication and unfavorable changes in the aquatic ecosystems; * nitrate pollution of subsurface water caused by liquid manure application and irrational or improper N fertilizer application not adequately selected for the crop requirement (nutrient uptake), soil properties, and weather conditions, time of application, etc.; and * pesticides and other organic chemicals pollution; 40. Soil erosion (strong surface runoff, lack of permanent cover of crops, steep slopes, heavy rainfall but limited infiltration), implies considerable loss of organic matter and plant nutrients, silting of waterways, canals, and reservoirs, and increases the cost of more frequent cleaning and increasing hazards of water logging and floods in the lower parts of the watershed. Private Sector 41. The practice of integrated, extensive production and greater coverage of livestock is the reason why soil conditions are much better among private farms. Nevertheless, on some soils of private households, the process of intensive erosion had been registered, particularly in the northwestern Pannonian subregion, as well as in the complete Mediterranean area. Besides natural factors, one reason for this situation is the unfavorable orientation of plots and plowing up and down the slope. In addition, erosion is aggravated by the mix of main crops, especially when the rotation includes maize. 42. Deposition of herbicides in these zones accumulates in the mountain base, leaching into the water flows, which in turn causes water pollution. These pesticide residues lead to water eutrophication among the water flows. Water pollution by nitrates also appears on sites where large quantities of poultry manure are used on the acid, drained, light, gravely soils of northwestern Croatia.
