The Farmer Support Services Project is conceived to involve agricultural research, agricultural extension, animal health services, fodder and pasture development, seed industry development (through institutional and regulatory development), and strengthen MAF's policy formulation capacities. Since the Croatian private sector has historically been an avid supporter of ecologically sustainable agricultural production, progress in these fields will strengthen the future development of sustainable agriculture. 44. No negative environmental impacts are expected in the course of FSSP implementation. It is realistic to expect that the effects of some project components will strengthen the notion of sustainable agriculture which combines technologies, policies and activities aimed at integrating socioeconomic principles with environmental concerns so as to simultaneously: maintain or enhance production, minimize risk of diminished food production, protect natural resources and prevent degradation of soil and water quality, all with a view to being economically viable and socially acceptable. 45. This EA does not propose a specific mitigation plan (nor does it cost mitigation efforts) because no direct negative environmental impacts are anticipated in the context of implementing this project. However, as a crucial mitigation activity during the first year of project implementation, MAF would develop special ('best practice') guidelines for its extension service and the farming community in support of the concept and practices of sustainable agriculture and appropriate handling of agriculture chemicals. 46. A major contribution to the development of these best practice guidelines can be expected from the findings of the on-going project on "Proper Handling of Pesticides and their Residues in Agriculture Practice" managed by the Agency for Special and Dangerous Waste. 47. In addition, MAF will organize an "International Workshop on Water Pollution and Protection in Agriculture Practices" in Zagreb, in October, 1995. This workshop will be organized in the framework of the new international project on "Pollution of Ground and Surface Water by Nitrates, Heavy Metals and Pesticides through Percolation from Agriculture Areas" which has been suggested by Croatia and accepted by the Third Session of the FAO/ECE Working Party on Relations between Agriculture and Environment, held in Geneva in 1994. B. EXPECTED TRENDS 48. It cannot be forgotten that private farmers have historically been economically discriminated against. Providing new economic power will lead to possible trends toward intensification of agricultural production. Due to a certain "hunger in agrochemicals application" an unfavorable "polarization" tendency in agrochemicals application may occur under two possible scenarios: Scenario A: Better soil - rich farmer - higner rate of agrochemical (in spite of the possible lower requirements) - better nutrient status of soil - overdosage Scenario B: Poor soil - poor farmer - lower rate of agrochemicals (in spite of the possible higher requirements) - lower nutrient supply of soils - underdosage
 Project Implementation Plan - 163 - ANNEX F 49. Certain new dangers may present themselves as new agricultural land users are motivated to realize as high a profit as possible in the short term. The short-term market-oriented production of land users may lead to environmental damager because of the lack of necessary (and sometimes expensive) preventive measures, especially in cases when harmful side-effects are detectable only one or two years later or when they appear in the surrounding environment (nitrate pollution, acidification). 50. Project implementation opens the way to a trend to overdosage under Scenario A (the "maximum concept" principle), which, if the problem does not get sufficient attention, may cause various environmental damages: * soil acidification; * contamination of drinking water resources by nitrate leaching; * accumulation of harmful toxic elements in the various stages of the "food chain". 51. However, project implementation also opens a set of desirable processes and effects, which will undoubtedly result positively on the environment. In the first place, FSSP finances research work which seeks to define optimal management practices in agriculture. Secondly, Extension Service activities are financed to provide accurate and professional information about all aspects of ecologically risky management practices. In order to achieve this objective MAF would develop "Best Practices" Guidelines for its extension service on the concept and practice of sustainable agriculture and on the handling of agriculture chemicals. 52. In addition, privatization will increase ownership feeling and more care for maintaining long- run soil fertility and sustaining the environment. A private household, especially a family farm, allows for much more flexibility in sustainable agriculture. Market forces and EU integration will orient production towards quality standards and environmental aspects in general; such a concept will be a guiding principle in the professional advice provided by the Extension Service. 53. The FSSP is to a large extent focused on institutional strengthening and development. Individual components are anticipated to have a beneficial impact on the environment as follows: (i) the Agriculture Extension Component would enhance the dissemination of environmentally relevant knowledge through the special guidelines developed by MAF from international and national research; (ii) the Applied Agriculture Research Component would allow the investigation of pressing environmental issues related to agriculture; (iii) the Animal Health Component would ensure a better control of contagious and zoonotic diseases; (iv) the Pasture and Fodder Development Component would contribute to better erosion control, landscape management (reduction of maize monoculture), and more animal- friendly husbandry practices; (v) the Seed Industry Development Component would by improving the regulatory framework ensure better and more rapid access to new, disease and pest resistant plant genetic materials already available abroad which would enhance low input practices in crop management; through the establishment of the National Seed Authority agrochemical
 ANNEX F - 164 - Project Implementation Plan testing and registration as well as the development of integrated pest management (IPM) practices would be integrated into one institution thus ensuring efficient development of regulations and procedures. (vi) the Policy Analysis Support Component would increase MAF's capability to follow actual developments related to environmental issues in the agricultural sector and concerns of decision makers in view of including these issues into appropriate legislation. C. LAND MANAGEMENT FOR SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE 54. The development of Croatian agriculture to increase food and agricultural production while meeting unsatisfied demand and recognizing the need to use environmentally friendly technologies will carry forward into the 21st century. The main "pillars" and principles of Sustainable Land Development (SLM)-Productivity, Security, Protection, Viability and Acceptability-(according to a Discussion Paper of the Land and Water Development Division of FAO) are fully compatible with Croatian conditions. It is clear that sustainable land management needs to be in the center of environmentally sound sustainable agriculture. 55. Implementation of FSSP will open the way to scientifically-based crop production technologies, in particular with regard to: adequate crop rotation, integral plant nutrition systems including plant residue management and integrated pest management system. In other words, FSSP by our judgment opens the way to knowledge-based instead of high input-based agriculture. 56. Experts of the extension service will need to keep in mind that quality of surface and subsurface water resources and protection of the environment are required for the long-term sustainability of agriculture. We consider that ideas expressed through the FSSP would support this concept. Criteria of sustainable agricultural development and crop production would need to be defined and quantified in the context of the aforementioned Extension Guidelines. IV. SUMMARY STATUS OF ENVIRONMENTAL LEGISLATION 57. Environmental legislation in the Republic of Croatia is not yet formed as a uniform and systematic body of laws. However, since individual parts of this legislation are covered by laws on water protection, agricultural land protection, forest protection etc., and these parts have a long tradition and have been systematically developed, environmental legislation could be considered complete as a combination of theses laws and on a regulatory level. Some parts of environment legislation are developed on a sectoral basis (water-management, agriculture, forestry etc.). 58. Generally, Croatian environmental legislation is characterized by the following features: * a variable degree of development of some parts of the legislation through a number of bodies directly responsible for development, monitoring and implementation, and inefficiency in enforcement and control; * the general character of legislation is mainly guiding, partly resulting in inefficient implementation, and less of a restricting and obligatory nature; and
 Project Implementation Plan - 165 - ANNEX F a strong legal activity related to changing the present and setting new regulations based on constitutional prescriptions, (i.e., a need to harmonize with new social and economic orientation of the Republic of Croatia), which means introducing modern legislation solutions. 59. The approach practiced in solving environmental questions is based on a broader, integrated approach characterized by a long positive tradition of multidisciplinary work and intersectoral co- operation, which is based not on regulations, but rather on experience. It has to be noted that, in former Yugoslavia, issues of environment protection had been solved at the republic level, so that in the Republic of Croatia there was continuity in improving the activities of environment protection, particularly since the beginning of 1970s, and environment legislation had involved regulations set in the period from 1949 to present day. 60. It can be expected that projects such as FSSP will positively influence the process of completing and strengthening environmental legislation. V. RELEVANT LEGISLATION FOR FSSP IMPLEMENTATION 61. Central elements of environmental protection are covered by the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia from 1990 which stipulates that: (i) the environment is under special protection by the State; (ii) citizens right to a healthy life and a healthy environment are guaranteed; and (iii) citizens' right to local self-government involves also the right to make decisions on environment protection and improvement. 62. The Declaration on Environment Protection in the Republic of Croatia (MN 34/92) is oriented toward "an agriculture based on economically sustainable development...., and imposes: "...rational soil management as an important measure, with the purpose of food production; to be achieved by applying strong protection, by prohibiting the reallocation of highly productive soils to non-agricultural use, especially building purposes; by improving the lower categories of soil; by encouraging agricultural production on fallow areas and by strictly controlling pesticide use as well as other substances for plan protection, respectively..." 63. Law on Environment Protection (MN982/94) prescribes a common starting point for systematic actions in the field of environmental protection, and represent legislative starting point from which legal solutions of particular environmental issues arise. This law consists of basic principles of environment protection, determines creation of documents, the ways and means of implementing environmental protection (standards, environmental impact assessment, monitoring, pollution cadastre, information system, etc.), responsibility, control and penalties. As such, practical issues are solved mainly by other laws and regulations. 64. Law on Trade of Poisons (NN 53/91, 26/93, 37/94), determines a list of prohibited and permitted poisons, classification of poisons in six classes (I to VI) and procedures for the trade of these poisons. A new law is currently in the legislative process and is expected to be passed by Parliament soon. The new law proposal has been developed in accordance with the WHO standards, details of which will be further governed by new, additional regulations.
 ANNEX F - 166 - Project Implementation Plan 65. Law on Production. Trade and Use of Poison (NN 20/83, 47/89, 26/93, 37/94) regulates the production of poisons and provides detailed regulations for the trade and use of poisons which are permitted by the Law on Trade of Poisons. According to this law, the production and use of poison may be prohibited in spite of its proper application, if it is found that it endangers the health and life of people or damages the environment. Each plant pesticide is required to pass a prescribed procedure to obtain permission for trade and use which is based on a number of tests as prescribed in the regulations. 66. Law on Water (MN 53/90, 9.91, 61.91, 43/93, 75/93. 75/94), amongst other, regulates issues of water supply, preventive water protection from pollution, and measures for decreasing water contamination, including designing water-management plans, issuing of water-management permits, control and penalties. 67. Law on Spatial Planning (MN 30.94). Spatial planning arrangements have a long tradition in the Republic of Croatia. Total space of the state - its purpose, use and conditions for protection are determined by the Spatial Plan of the Republic of Croatia (MN 12/89) and spatial plans of municipalities. Spatial plans are created as coordinating documents involving all basic elements of sectoral development - for example, water-management plans, forest-management plans, traffic plans etc. All operations in space are carried out exclusively on the basis of such spatial plans. 68. Law on Agricultural Land (MN 54/94, 65/94). This law prescribes basic terms of protection, usage and reallocation of agricultural land, use over state-owned agricultural land, and control and penalties. 69. Law on Plant Protection (MN 10/94. 19/94) regulates in detail the protection of plants and plant products from pests, plant health control, transport of pesticides and prevention of negative consequence of their use on humans, animals and environment, including control and penalties. 70. Law on livestock production improvement measures (MN 11/79, 26/93) and Law on animal health protection and veterinary activities (MN 52/91, 26/93) determine a general framework for the improvement of livestock production and for systematic animal health protection, (i.e., veterinary activities). 71. Inspection control. The public inspection activities are prescribed by a broad range of laws. Part of the control and monitoring of FSSP implementation is carried out by environmental protection inspection, agricultural inspection, water management inspection, veterinary inspection, plant-protection inspection, town-planning inspection, construction inspection, and sanitary inspection. 72. The Republic of Croatia is a signatory member to a number of international conventions on the protection of the environment such as (i) Protocol on the Mediterranean Protection from Continental Pollution (Barcelona Convention Protocol) regarding the Adriatic part of Croatia; (ii) Convention on the Cooperation on the Protection and Sustainable Use of the River Danube; and (iii) Convention on Biological Diversity Protection, which have legal precedence over national law. 73. Regulation on the study of Environmental Impact Assessment (MN 31/84). Regulations require an EIA for the food-processing industry, livestock and poultry farrms capacities over 500 heads, slaughter-houses capacities over 50 head and tanneries. 74. Law on Nature Protection (MN 30/94, 72/94) prescribes procedures for obtaining licenses for construction works and other works on non-construction locations.
 Project Implementation Plan - 167 - ANNEX F 75. Regulations based on the Law on Water govern: (i) dangerous and harmful substances which cannot be flowed or get into the water, or deposited on areas where the possibility of water pollution exists, except under prescribed terms; water classification and categorization; terms to determine the zones of sanitary source protection and protective measures - (Regulation on water categories [MN 15/81]); (ii) Regulations on maximal permitted concentration of danger substances in waters and coastal see (2/84), Regulation on protective measures on terms for determining the sanitary protection variation of fresh water sources (MN 22/86), Plan for protection of water from pollution (MN 22/86), Instruction on record keeping on frequency of emissions of dangerous and harmful substances, their quantities and composition, to the waters (MN 22/86). 76. Regulations on agricultural land protection for contamination with harmful substances (MN 15/92) regulate the content of ecologically risky substances allowed, and determines how many and when the manure can be used. The maximum tolerated contaminant content is determined by the Rule Book on Agricultural Soil Conservation. 77. Legislation regarding management of chemicals involves chemicals for plan protection (I I regulations), mineral fertilizers (4 regulations) and veterinary drugs (4 regulations). These regulations govern the protection from harmful impacts on human environment, classifications and registration, information requirements and transport. Regulations of major importance are: * Law on quality, quality control an distribution of mineral fertilizers (MN 43/93) * Regulations on Fertilizer Register and Fertilizer Declaring (MN 43/92) * Regulations on minimal and maximal substances and other characteristics of particular sorts of mineral fertilizers (MN 43/92) * Set of sub-legal provisions regulates food protection issues - from animal control and control of animal products, to the quality of certain kinds of food products. 78. A modern environmental monitoring system is currently being developed encompassing all the existing data bases, information and related services. It is a long-term project developed by the State Directorate of Environment in cooperation with many other ministries and services envisaged to be developed in accordance with international monitoring networks. The concept of this project is to obtain an integrated and decentralized monitoring system. Presently, data on air, soil and water are made available by numerous different administrative bodies, services and institutions. 79. From the above summary of the existing laws and regulations, the following could be concluded with regard to the implementation of FSSP: * existing provisions have more of a guiding than a restrictive role; * the restrictions are mostly related to land use and development of a particular area, and to some extent to the application of chemicals; 80. Estimates of air, water and soil contamination for larger urban centers (Zagreb, Rijeka, Sisak, Kutina)' and estimates of harmful substances emission from agriculture are carried out and generally 1/ Controlling and information cadastre system of polluters (NISO) by State Directorate of Environment.
 ANNEX F - 168 - Project Implementation Plan analyzed based on produced quantities of fertilizers, consumption of fuel and lubricant for agricultural machines, emission of harmful substances from fertilizer plants and share in liquid waste. Continuous monitoring of harmful substances emission into the environment and of impacts caused by agricultural production at the national level in Croatia still does not exist. According to the soil monitoring, created within the working group for soil protection in Alps-Adria and Danube basin countries, the permanent "monitoring" of soil, will be carried out in Croatia with the purpose of monitoring the essential soil characteristics, particularly natural contents, anthropogene influence and ecological risky substances balance. Soil monitoring and analysis will be carried out using standardized methods in all member- states, which provides coordination in soil protection measures. 81. The general environmental situation in Croatia is deemed to be satisfactory. Some environmental contamination, in some cases above European and World standard limits, are registered in highly industrialized and urban areas (Zagreb, Rijeka, Sisak, Kutina). The general share of agriculture in total emission of harmful substances is highly variable, but significantly below the level of industrial emissions. For example, the share of exhausted nitrogen (NO) from agriculture is estimated at 15-25 %, while share of industrial deposition is about 50%. The share of phosphorus deposition (P205) is about 10%, which is significantly less than industrial influence (60-70%). The major part of agricultural pollution by nitrate and phosphorus related to water pollution. Estimates of Sok emission, based on total consumption of fuel and contents of sulfur in some kinds of fuel, shows that agricultural machinery utilization accounts for about 5 % of the total air pollution in Croatia. 82. The relatively low levels of NO, SO,, and P04 emissions from agriculture so far are the result of ownership structure and the economic positions of Croatian agriculture producers. Namely, the greater part of agricultural and arable land, agricultural mechanization, as well as livestock assets are family farm-owned, whose consumption of fertilizers and pesticides, and mechanization utilization is in most cases considerably lower, due to its inferior economic position, limited agricultural acreage, traditional production organization and (dis)parity of input and output prices. Even the intensive production family farms have no particular crop or livestock capacities which could, due to their size and location on small areas, significantly influence the increase of emission of harmful substances into environment. 83. Currently no manual exists to guide farmers on the application, handling, and storage of agricultural inputs, and it is recommended to include the development of such a manual within the extension component of the FSSP. 84. More attention should be given to the appropriate development of the role of the agriculture extension services, as well as promotion of NGOs to introduce practical approaches to integrated and sustainable agriculture. The role and coordination of inspection activities should be strengthened. The regular control of soil fertility should be enforced to the extent possible. REFERENCES 1. doc.abstracts: The Farmer Support Services Project will support the government of Croatia's agricultural policy by efficiently providing technology-related support services that are relevant to the private farmers. The aim is to improve the income of the private farming community and increase its productivity and hence the competitiveness of the sector. The project will address the need: 1) to change delivery mechanisms for the provision of technical services to the private farming community; and 2) for institutional restructuring to meet the needs of a market economy. Increased farmer ownership and accountability of the agricultural knowledge system are also essential elements of project design. The provision of relevant and efficient veterinary services and support for the shift from a grain-based animal production system to a lower cost pasture-based livestock industry are other central objectives. In addition, rationalizing the regulatory framework for the seed industry will be supported. The project will furthermore seek to strengthen the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry's policy formulation capabilities and the agriculture data base in order to ensure more rational policy decisions in the future. Finally, the project consists of the six following components: 1) extension; 2) research; 3) animal health; 4) pasture and fodder development; 5) seed industry development; and 6) policy analysis support.
